did.abstract:
The son of William Franklin, Royal Governor of New Jersey, William Temple Franklin worked as aide to his grandfather, Benjamin Franklin, when the latter served as minister to France during the American Revolution. A bonvivant, Temple received his highest public appointment as Secretary to the American delegation at the Treaty of Versailles in 1782-1783, largely through the influence of his famous grandfather, but never again attained a significant post. As Franklin's literary heir, he edited and published a three volume set of his grandfather's writings in 1817. He married his long time mistress a few months before his death in Paris in 1823.
The William Temple Franklin Papers provides a richly detailed portrait of the life of the grandson of Benjamin Franklin, and consists largely of letters received during the years that Temple served as his grandfather's aide in France, 1776-1785. Although much of the correspondence is routine, during this period, Temple received regular reports from friends and diplomatic colleagues relaying information on the American Revolution, the course of diplomatic and peace negotiations, and French public opinion on Benjamin Franklin and the new United States. The collection is also a rich resource for information on the personal lives of the Franklins, including interesting correspondence from Temple's relatives William Franklin, Elizabeth Franklin, Sarah Franklin Bache, and Jonathan Williams, and his mistress Blanchette Caillot.
did.physloc: LH-MV-D-8 (B F86); LH-MV-C-9 (B F86x); LH-SB-Black Case-27 (CII,38; CVII,56; CVII,71)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Shortly after his birth in London in 1760, William Temple Franklin was sent out to be raised by a string of foster mothers. The illegitimate son of Benjamin Franklin's illegitimate son William and of an unidentified woman of apparently ill repute, Temple was kept far away from the public eye as his father advanced in career and social standing. When Temple was two, his father married respectably and left England to become Royal Governor of New Jersey, and only at age four would Temple begin his slow integration into the fractious Franklin family.

Kept ignorant of his parentage, Temple was introduced into Franklin's Craven Street home as "William Temple," a protégé of his grandfather, while the expenses of his lodging and schooling were funneled quietly through Margaret Stevenson to his absent father. Temple enjoyed the benefits of an excellent education and an amiable social circle and was considered a charming, if sometimes irresponsible young boy, yet it was only years later, when he was asked to accompany his grandfather on his return to Philadelphia in the spring of 1775, that he was at last apprised of his identity. The news, as he soon discovered, was a mixed blessing. Simmering tensions between Benjamin and William over both personal and political differences came to head in May 1775 when the three generations of Franklins met in at Joseph Galloway's farm at Trevose, Bucks County, Pa., to reacquaint themselves and attempt to reconcile. Rather than reunion, however, this meeting provoked a rancorous split between the elder, headstrong Franklins, with the flighty Temple caught in the middle. Although Temple left Trevose with William to become acquainted over the summer, Benjamin insisted that he return to Philadelphia in the fall to begin college -- and not coincidentally, to remain under Benjamin's close supervision.

At the end of an indifferent year at the College of Philadelphia, Temple received news that his father had been declared "an enemy to the liberties of this country" and thrown into prison. Benjamin grew alarmed when Temple decided to travel to New Jersey late in the summer to console his step-mother Elizabeth, and wrote to his grandson to express concern for his safety being so near British lines, but beneath that, he feared that Temple was falling under the sway of Loyalist sympathies. Having already lost a son to the Tories, Benjamin was determined not to lose his grandson. In early September, Benjamin quashed Temple's request to visit his father in prison, claiming at first that useful intelligence might be passed to the enemy, but adding later that he prevented the visit out of "tender Concern" for Temple's welfare during the perilous trip to Connecticut.

In the long run, Benjamin won out in the contest for Temple's loyalties, and when the aging diplomat was called upon to travel to France to secure support for the American cause late in September 1776, Temple came along as his personal aide. From his grandfather's side, Temple was provided with a uniquely privileged view on the sensitive negotiations between the fledgling United States and the French crown, and his grandfather regularly favored him with highly visible assignments to prepare him for future betterment. In December 1777, for example, Temple was selected to deliver the critically important Treaty of Amity between France and the new United States to the French ministry.

Yet despite his grandfather's assistance, Temple did little to distinguish himself, attracting a chorus of doubters as time progressed. Grown into a feckless, seemingly aimless young man, Temple was inclined to dandyism and took to the social life in France with as deep an enthusiasm as his grandfather, but without the wit or intellectual depth, and certainly without the personal discipline and commitment to Republican principles. Worse, Temple seems to have acquired an aptitude for infelicitous choices, gladly embracing the Mesmerist fad, for example, despite his grandfather's reservations on the subject, and even joining the pro-Mesmer Société d'Harmonie. Perhaps to prove his mettle and his commitment to serious matters, Temple teamed up with the Marquis de Lafayette in the summer of 1779 (a fellow fan of Mesmer) to plan an invasion of Britain, but like many of Temple's plans, this one never came to pass.

Despite his grandson's insouciance, Benjamin continued to work on Temple's behalf, initiating him into his Masonic Loge des Neuf Soeurs and scheming, as he once had for William, to see Temple marry well. In 1781, Benjamin attempted to strike a match between Temple and Cunegonde, daughter of Franklin's beloved Mme Brillon. "Having almost lost my own daughter because of the wide distance between us," he wrote to Mme Brillon, "I hoped to find another one in you, and still another in your daughter, to take care of my old age." Citing Temple's Protestantism as an excuse, however, the Brillons rejected the union. In characteristic Franklin fashion, Temple rebounded by taking up with a married neighbor at Passy, Blanchette Caillot, with whom he had a natural son, Théodore.

Through his grandfather's influence in 1782 -- and over the opposition even of many of Benjamin's allies -- Temple landed the most important assignment of his career when he was appointed as Secretary to the Peace Commission. But rather than advancing his prospects, this appointment may actually have hindered them by piquing the jealousy and animosity of his rivals. It is likely that the failure of Benjamin's efforts to win a ministerial appointment for Temple in 1783 can be attributed to a combination of resentment over Benjamin's manipulation and Temple's personality, which everyone but Benjamin now considered disreputable. When Polly Stevenson visited Benjamin at Passy in 1784, even she was disimpressed with the man Temple had become, writing that he had become "so engaged in the pursuit of pleasure that he is not an amiable or respectable character."

Before their returning to the United States in 1785, Benjamin and Temple parlayed with William yet again in a half-hearted attempt to work out their differences. Although there was no reconciliation, William agreed (not entirely willingly) to aid his son by selling him his New Jersey and New York properties at a bargain price. When Benjamin died on April 17, 1790, Temple inherited his library and became his literary executor. Although this seemed to instill an enthusiasm in Temple over plans to publish his grandfather's works, once again things did not go as planned. Gathering the manuscript of the autobiography and some important correspondence that he intended to use to update it, Temple returned to England in 1792 only to find that a French translation of it had already appeared. He decided, however, to continue on with his project, working slowly to produce a more complete edition.

Reuniting with his father in 1792, still unmarried, Temple chafed under William's demands that he find a wife, and shortly after fathering another illegitimate child, Ellen, with the daughter of his father's second wife, Temple broke bitterly away and moved to Paris. Without his grandfather's guiding hand, Temple continued on the same aimless path. His three volume edition of the Memoirs of the Life and Writings of Benjamin Franklin did not appear until 1817. He lived the last six years of his life with his English mistress Hannah Collyer, whom he finally married a months before his death in 1823.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The William Temple Franklin Papers provides a richly detailed portrait of the life of the grandson of Benjamin Franklin, concentrated in letters received by Temple in the years that he served as his grandfather's aide in France, 1776-1785. Although much of the correspondence is perfunctory, during this period, Temple received regular reports from friends and diplomatic colleagues relaying information on the American Revolution, the course of diplomatic and peace negotiations, and French public opinion on Benjamin Franklin and the new United States.

The collection is equally valuable for providing insight into the personal lives of the Franklins, their sometimes contentious family life, indiscretions, and their intricate web of personal quarrels and alliances. The letters from Temple's father William and step-mother Elizabeth provide a glimpse into the stress Temple must have endured during his father's imprisonment during the summer of 1776, and Temple was in regular friendly contact with his aunt Sarah Bache Franklin and kinsman Jonathan Williams. There are also over 40 letters from Blanchette Caillot, Temple's mistress and mother of his son who died early.

Upon calendaring, the W. T. Franklin Papers were bound into volumes in roughly chronological order. Although the collection has been rearranged chronologically, we have retained the original volume and folio numbers for reference purposes.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.p: The Printed Materials Department also houses most of the works published or edited by William Temple Franklin, including: Franklin, William Temple, The Private Correspondence of Benjamin Franklin (London, 1817). Call no.: B F85f763. Franklin, William Temple, Memoirs of the Life and Writings of Benjamin Franklin, 3 vols. (London, 1818). Call no.: B F85f77.See also: Franklin, Benjamin, Mémoires de la Vie Privée ... Écrits par lui Même et Adressés à Son Fils (Paris, 1791). Call no.: B F85f76.
bibliography.bibref: Franklin, William Temple, Sketch of William Temple Franklin's services to the United-States of America (Philadelphia, 1789). Call no.: Broadside 973 C583 no.482.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids note
otherfindaid.p: Most of the William Temple Franklin Papers are calendared in I. Minis Hays, Calendar of the Papers of Benjamin Franklin, Vol. 5 (Philadelphia: APS, 1908).

odd.head: Naval History Note
odd.p: The William Temple Franklin Papers contain several letters which may be of interest to naval historians:

list.head: Barry, John, 1745-1803.
list.item: Ross, John. Letter to William Temple Franklin. 1780 October 2. Owing to adverse winds they have not been able to sail. A brig has just arrived from Philadelphia reporting the safe arrival of the Alliance. Captain Pierre Landais was put under arrest and the Alliance was to be offered to Captain John Barry. 2 pages. (CII, 119).
Barclay, Thomas. Letter to William Temple Franklin. 1783 March 22. Relating to prize-money claimed by the Alliance and Commodore John Paul Jones' squadron. 1 page. (CV, 36).

list.head: Jones, John Paul, 1747-1792.
list.item: Jones, John Paul. Letter to William Temple Franklin. 1778 September 25. Tells of his letters to Dr. Franklin, Dr. [Edward] Bancroft, M. [Le Ray] de Chaumont, M. [Antoine Raymond Jean Gualbert Gabriel] de Sartine, etc., and his efforts to get a command. If disappointed again will be obliged to return to America unemployed, as he cannot remain inactive. 3 pages. (CI, 62).

Jones, John Paul. Letter to William Temple Franklin. 1778 October 13. Has written a letter to M. [Le Ray] de Chaumont which he requests William Temple Franklin to translate. Declares that his honor has received a public injury from M. [Antoine Raymond Jean Gualbert Gabriel] de S[artine] and that it must be righted. 1 page. (CI, 69).

Jones, John Paul. Letter to William Temple Franklin. 1778 October 28. Considers M. [Le Ray] de Chaumont's plan to buy a frigate or corvette to be commanded by him (Jones) would require too much time and negotiation. Has seen Mr. Joseph [P.] Whitall who is at Brest and who saw the Indian at Amsterdam, which could be armed and sail in two weeks. Declares M. [Antoine Raymond Jean Gualbert Gabriel] de Sartine has wronged him. Hopes he will be given command of the Indian and that M. de Sartine will give him credentials and testimonials to justify him before Congress and his friends. Has many enemies, as no man in the Navy has pursued the same line of service as himself. 3 pages. (CI, 71).

Jones, John Paul. Letter to William Temple Franklin. 1778 November 16. Requests him to explain a letter which he encloses. Has received another very kind from the Duke de la R[ochefoucauld]. Intends to leave for l'Orient shortly. 1 page. (CI, 77).

Jones, John Paul. Letter to William Temple Franklin. 1780 November 11. Anxiety about his Excellency's health; has not yet received any papers or power to administer the oath of allegiance; advises that the public dispatches be sent as soon as possible. 1 page. (CII, 130).

Jones, John Paul. Letter to William Temple Franklin. 1784 May 31. Thinks it would be more consistent for him not to appear at Court, when the Act of Congress is presented authorizing him to accept the Order of Military Merit. 1 page. (CVI, 32).

list.head: Truxton, Thomas, 1755-1822.
list.item: Franks, Major David Salisbury. Letter to William Temple Franklin. 1781 December 10. Fears that his prolonged stay, waiting for a vessel, will be very expensive to the Government at home. The number of people arrived with the Franch fleets of war have caused a scarcity of necessaries of life; prices are very high. The "St. James," Capt. [Thomas] Truxton, probably the first vessel which will sail for America about January 15. His situation very unpleasant and embarrassing. Was arrested the other day on suspicion of being a spy. 3 pages. (CIII, 149).
Franklin, William Temple. Letter to Thomas Jefferson. 1785 July 20. Arrangements made with Captain Thomas Truxton. 3 pages. (B F86.15).

odd.head: Early American History Note
odd.p: This is a large collection of William Temple Franklin papers, most of which were written while he was serving alongside his grandfather in France as the secretary of the American mission there. The bulk of the collection is correspondence written to William Temple Franklin during the American Revolution. Franklin had a wide network of friends and associates, and this correspondence captures the range of dealings Franklin had in France. As secretary, he received intelligence, requests, reports of military actions, especially those pertaining to naval actions in the Atlantic, and various other communications. As a private individual, Franklin had relations with many merchants, traders, and land speculators and continued to cultivate these relationships while in Europe. The Collection also includes a diary kept in an almanac for much of 1785, catalogued separately in MOLE.

Combined with Benjamin Franklin’s Papers, the account books from the delegation, the Benjamin Franklin Bache Collection, and the John Adams Papers on microfilm, the APS has an extraordinarily strong record of the United States’ diplomacy during the American Revolution. Notable among the correspondents to William Temple Franklin is John Paul Jones, who was a regular correspondent to both William Temple and Benjamin Franklin.

The early portion of the collection contains a series of letters between William and Eliza Franklin and William Temple Franklin written before the American Revolution. The long letters touch upon William Temple’s education and on politics. The personal nature of the letters also provides insight into the family relations of the Franklin family during this very divisive period of the family’s history. Numerous letters from Sarah Franklin Bache and Benjamin Franklin Bache to William Temple can also be found in this collection.

This collection, along with the various other Fox Collections, chronicles William Temple Franklin’s career after the American Revolution, much of which was spent in Europe. William Temple Franklin inherited his grandfather’s papers, which he edited for publication, and later bequeathed to George Fox, whose family gifted them and William Temple Franklin’s papers to the APS.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On his departure from London with Franklin for America. News of friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Referring to the kind reception William Temple Franklin received from his father (Gov. William Franklin) on arriving in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Giving advice to William Temple Franklin; hopes he will return to England to complete his education.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Giving his son advice about his studies. Several references to his father, Benjamin Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending items of news about friends and acquaintances. Tells of the Major's [?] marriage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring about his son's studies, his health, etc. Advice about letter writing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to the dancing and fencing schools. Has a translation of Livy, but thinks his son should not use one.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to a barrel of oysters Mrs. Franklin is sending to him. Wishes to know when his father is expected home.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to articles of dress purchased for her Mrs. [Richard] Bache. Items of local news about mutual friends and acquaintances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complains of the abuse he and his wife have been subjected to recently. Speaks of his difficult situation. The indignities he has received. Much concerned about his wife who has no relatives in this country; refers to slights she has received from his own relatives. Wants a copy of "Common Sense" [by Thomas Paine, Philadelphia, 1776].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is surprised that all his friends did not hear of reports spread about him. Refers to money matters; tells his son to be economical, as he has little to give him. Wishes a copy of the 3d edition of "Common Sense."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is greatly concerned about his father's proposed journey to Canada. Thinks it ill-advised and dangerous. Requests his son to send him several political pamphelts. Advises him not to neglect his studies in Latin and French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Giving his son directions how to come to Amboy when he gets his holidays. Refers to money matters between him, his son and Mr. [Richard] Bache.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reproves his son for spending his allowance too fast. Asks for certain numbers of the "[Pennsylvania] Evening Post" and "Pennsylvania Ledger."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a due note to be given to Mr. [Richard] Bache for collection from Mr. Hooper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reproves his son for imprudent spending of his allowance. Is glad to hear of his father's safe return; would be glad to hear that he had resolved to quit all public business. Requests several copies of pamphlet "Strictures on Common Sense." [True Interest of America Impartially Stated, in certain Strictures, on a Pamphlet entitled Common Sense. By an American (Charles Inglis), Philadelphia, 1776.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reproaches his son for not being more punctual in attending to his orders. Anxious to hear how his father is after his recent journey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been ordered to set out, under guard, for Princeton. Was suffering from a high fever; his departure postponed for a day. Bids adieu to his son.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Stoppage of the stage service. Cannot forward newspapers to Mrs. [Elizabeth] Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Speaks of his approaching visit to her. Requests him to bring her some money from Mr. [Richard] Bache. Alludes to her troubles and fears.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to his return to Philadelphia. Encloses two letters for friends in that city.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is anxious to hear what is the advantageous offer made to him by his grandfather. Complains bitterly that her letters to her husband are not allowed to pass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will not go to Mr. [Joseph] Galloway's till Sunday. He can go there directly or go to Burlington.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advises him to see Chevalier de Ferrière's house at once and rent it, if it suits him.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to pay Mrs. [Margaret] Stevenson £55 which he owes her. Requests him to attend to the transaction. Wishes three or four of Dr. Franklin's profiles which Mr. [Le Ray] de Chaumont has has made at his Fayence factory.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting William Temple Franklin to execute a few private commissions for him in Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Had expected to see him and Doctor Franklin at Nantes. Inquires if the plan has been given up.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a packet of his grandfather; bids him good-bye; asks to be remembered to Mr. [Silas] Deane, who must appoint a day to see his cannon at the arsenal.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to draft for £55 payable to Mrs. [Margaret] Stevenson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells of cost of making a vat for experiments with different kinds of air or gar.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for news sent, but would have wished it had been confirmed by letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests a copy of the last general letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An account of his journey from Paris. Met Mr. [John] Adams at Angoulê"me. Embargo placed on English vessels a great loss to the latter; French and neutral vessels now getting all the West India trade.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives his opinion of the bills passed in England with regard to America. States what he considers the only terms acceptable to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects Franklin to dinner. Would like him to remain for tea. Requests him, if he has any favorite tea, to bring some in his pocket. Would like Mme. Brillon to come also.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will send a couple of rifles at first opportunity. The pistols are designed for use by cavalry and not fit for an affair of honor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging him to find the plan of Gibraltar which was submitted to Dr. Franklin by M. [Barbeu] Dubourg, and to give it to his servant; desires news of Mr. [Jonathan] Williams [Jr.]'s health.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for sending his thermometer and the Resolutions of Congress. Refers to the English Ministry's conduct towards Ireland. Trade with America and the West Indies not interrupted. Is learning Franch and attends the theatre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the English original of the "Conscious Lovers." Invites him to dine.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Rochefoucauld, Louis Alexandre, duc de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for sending the Resolutions of Congress. Informs him of Capt. [John Paul] Jones's return to Brest after a brilliant cruise. Alludes to an expedition by Marquis de Lafayette.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends his compliments and thanks for newspaper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets that he was absent when William Temple Franklin paid a visit to his parents at La Cour Neuve.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Many of the Genevese have British sympathies. A certain patriotic gentleman from Carolina, wishes to know him (Franklin).
(In Latin.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending his respects and best wishes. Refers to Mrs. [Margaret] Stevenson, Mrs. [Mary] Hewson, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells of the loss of two of his vessels in American waters. Complains of the treachery of American pilots, secretly aiding the English.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking information about some Loan Office Certificates.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has registered himself as an American. Tells of arrivals of French trading vessels. The people are anxious to hear about Comte d'Estaing and the fleet from Brest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him to procure a permit for his baggage detained at Calais. Complains of the delay and trouble he has had.
(Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complains of the discourtesy shown him by Dr. Franklin and of the latter's neglect of his duties.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests to return a draft on the Commissioners payable to Van den Yver Frères and Co.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends his best wishes for the success of the American armies. Invites him to visit them. His wife and he are learning to play chess.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invites William Temple Franklin to spend a month with him and see the vintage. Offers to send him a supply of claret.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Receipt for a package.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter from Capt. [Peter] Collas. Requests William Temple Franklin to buy him a pair of pistols.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers to deliver a letter to Mr. Coxe on his way to Holland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests that care be taken of the furniture, plate, etc., belonging to him at Passy until his return.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Made a public communication of good news received. Requests prompt reply from Dr. Franklin as to providing food and clothing for poor American sailors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Comments on the good news received from America. Regrets that he cannot come on a visit and enjoy a wild boar hunt.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Conway, Françoise-Antoinette-Jeanne Langlois du Bouchet, comtesse de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires about her husband's reported illness. Thinks the prospect very bright for the independence of America. Hopes to be at Philadelphia soon.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires if Mr. [William] Blake, of [South] Carolina, has arrived in Paris and requests that particular attention and courtesy be shown to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is leaving on a tour of inspection of military schools. Requests William Temple Franklin to send him any important news he may receive.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Conway, Françoise-Antoinette-Jeanne Langlois du Bouchet, comtesse de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires about the truth of the report of her husband's serious illness.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter for Mr. [William] Blake.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter from Mr. [John] Vaughan and one for Capt. [Daniel] McNeill of the "Mifflin".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter for Capt. [Daniel] McNeill. Refers to Capt. [Peter] Collas and the return of the Brest fleet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells of his letters to Dr. Franklin, Dr. [Edward] Bancroft, M. [Le Ray] de Chaumont, M. [Antoine Raymond Jean Gualbert Gabriel] de Sartine, etc., and his efforts to get a command. If disappointed again will be obliged to return to America unemployed, as he cannot remain inactive.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Conway, Françoise-Antoinette-Jeanne Langlois du Bouchet, comtesse de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring about the report of her husband's duel with Col. [John] Cadwalader.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Learned of the taking of the "Fox" and the entry of the French fleet yesterday. The Marquis de Lafayette made a present of a snuff box with Dr. Franklin's portrait on it, to the young man who escorted her on board the American vessels here. Reports about Comte d'Estaing's fleet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter for Capt. [Daniel] McNeill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests William Temple Franklin to forward a letter to Gen. [Johann] de Kalb then in Paris, and to send his sister and him any news received about Gen. [Thomas] Conway.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has formed a partnership with a firm at Richmond as Adams, Deane and Co., and another at Baltimore as Smith, Harvey, Southall and Co. Requests him to mention their houses to European merchants making inquiry.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to a dispute between him and Mr. [John D.] Schweighauser of Nantes. Has heard reports of the capture of Rhode Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has written a letter to M. [Le Ray] de Chaumont which he requests William Temple Franklin to translate. Declares that his honor has received a public injury from M. [Antoine Raymond Jean Gualbert Gabriel] de S[artine] and that it must be righted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends correspondence relating to dispute with [Arthur] Lee. The latter after employing him has refused to reimburse his expenses.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Considers M. [Le Ray] de Chaumont's plan to buy a frigate or corvette to be commanded by him (Jones) would require too much time and negotiation. Has seen Mr. Joseph [P.] Whitall who is at Brest and who saw the "Indian" at Amsterdam, which could be armed and sail in two weeks. Declares M. [Antoine Raymond Jean Gualbert Gabriel] de Sartine has wronged him. Hopes he will be given command of the "Indian" and that M. de Sartine will give him credentials and testimonials to justify him before Congress and his friends. Has many enemies, as no man in the Navy has pursued the same line of service as himself.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is in great difficulties for lack of funds. Hopes Dr. Franklin will help him if Mr. [Arthur] Lee will pay him nothing.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was told Mr. [John] Williams, of London, was now in Paris. Asks for his address.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was ill and could not give his lessons. Hopes to see him on Thursday.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Distress of the wine merchants of Bordeaux caused by interruption of trade between the port and Great Britain and Ireland. Trade now partly carried on in Dutch vessels. Is a protection for French property. Requests him to obtain passes from Dr. Franklin for two such vessels bound for Englnd or Ireland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to search for a package of invoices which he think he left at

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to explain a letter which he encloses. Has received another very kind from the Duke de la R[ochefoucauld]. Intends to leave for l'Orient shortly; thinks he is an eye-sore to the Marine at Brest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Alludes to a purse which she made and gave to him. Does not believe he lacks material for writing; though he may sometimes not find time to do so.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will return Dr. Franklin's letter corrected under cover to Mme. Brillon. Asks to be remembered to Mr. [John] Adams and the [Le Ray] de Chaumont family.
(In French, English and Italian.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explains how trade is carried on, during hostilities, between Bordeaux and England and Ireland, in neutral vessels. Explains the reasons for asking passes for these vessels; withdraws his application for an American pass, it being no longer necessary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives an account of a riding accident which happened to him, on the day of William Temple Franklin's departure, whilst coming home at night from Versailles. Alludes to a visit to his family made by Mme. Lloyd. Sends the "Courrier de I'Europe" newspapers; many conjectures made as to the object of William Temple Franklin's journey. Refers to [Jacques] Necker's financial reforms, etc.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Does not yet know when he will leave France, but is very desirous to be at home, having learned of a death in the family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Looked carefully over the letters brought by the "General Washington." Is certain there is no other for him but the one forwarded.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to a vessel claiming to hail from Boston which called at Dieppe. Thinks it was an English vessel.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is about to leave for Boston and Virginia on a vessel loaded with supplies ordered by the State of Virginia. Will take charge of any messages or despatches Dr. Franklin may wish to send.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks about the truth of the report that Mr. [Henry] Laurens is going to Europe on a mission to France or Spain. Has had enquiries from Mrs. Laurens about the matter, also from young Harry Laurens. Mentions reports about [Admirals John] Byron, [Aug.us] Keppel and [Comte] d'Estaing. Refers to his brother John at Bordeaux; hears that the embargo on Irish provisions has been taken off. Intends to write to Dr. Franklin soon on some electrical conceits. Dr. [Joseph] Priestley is publishing a new book on Philosophy. Is sending Dr. Franklin the controversy between him (Dr. Priestley) and Dr. [Richard] Price.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to speak to M. [Antoine Raymond Jean Gualbert Gabriel] de Sartine about a claim for transportation of passengers from Miquelon, on one of his (Le Baron's) vessels, which he sent to the Minister of Marine.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes him a happy New Year which, in the beginning, will be agreeable for him for he goes to a "party of dance" and shall have a prize; was much frightened by the noise of a fire, which he thought was another rebellion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses two accounts from Mr. [Silas] Deane's coachman; asks that these be discharged.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets that he has not seen him before setting out.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his kind invitation and will inform the Commissioners [of the Academy] of the invitation to them likewise to dine with Dr. Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Leaves Paris so suddenly because of a cheap opportunity of travelling. Will return in six weeks to pay his debts, requests that all creditors be told this. Leaves a letter for Captain [John Paul] Jones.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received a letter from [John Paul] " Jones," but cannot read or answer it without his cipher. Asks William Temple Franklin to send it to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received the bust. Sends by Mr. Panchaud the "frauds of London" also Owen's and [Daniel] Paterson's books on the roads in England. Cannot raise any money here as the moneyed people will not take American security. Asks if it is possible to get a small supply of money in France. Mrs. Lloyd has given birth to another son.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires from the War Office about the report of the death, at Boston, of M. Deshays De la Radière, an officer in the Royal Engineer corps of France.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter and paper from Vaughan and requests him to reply to the latter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for the information about the "worst of villains." Implies that his reputation has been grievously injured by this person.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Had inteded to leave for home before now; has since learned that Capt. [Alexander] Gillon and his officers, whom he had given up as lost, are safe and back in France. Came here as a whim to enter the Navy, but does not intend to make it a profession.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sir James Norcliffe, Mr. Oliver's friend, has a brother in Burgoyne's army in Virginia and wishes to have him released; asks for Dr. Franklin's advice and assistance. Alludes to [Admirals Aug.us] Keppel and [Sir Hugh] Palliser and the latter's disgrace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to pay his initiation fee to the Masonic Lodge of the Nine Sisters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to have enclosed bills of exchange accepted and returned to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a few newspapers recently received from Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has discovered the person to whom the memorial related, and now encloses a letter from him to his friends. His father [Gov. William Franklin] is well and in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enlcosing Loan Office bills to be accepted and returned to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing two bills on the Commissioners and on Dr. Franklin to be accepted and returned.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will deliver Dr. Franklin's letter to David Hartley when the latter comes to town; the cartel for the American prisoners is under orders. Reports about the capture of Saint Lucia by the British under [Gen. James] Grant; blockade of the port by Comte d'Estaing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know what he thinks of the "History of Georgia" in "Le Courrier de L'Europe"; the English government appears to have made a great display; will have a few lances to break with such faultfinders and idiots.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Capt. Robenson, of South Carolina. Unexpected events oblige him (Waties) to return home.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires if it is probable that an Ensign in Burgoyne's army would be permitted to return to England to recover his health. Asks if it is true that Mr. [John] Adams has left Paris for America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The "Alliance" will be ready to go to Nantes in eight days. Introduces Mr. [Nathan] Blodget.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter to be copied. Invites him to dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explains a misunderstanding about some Loan Office bills sent by him for account of Mr. Cordis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His cousin [Jonathan Williams, 3d,] will arrive in Paris from l'Orient with Capt. [John Paul] Jones. Requests him to show him the sights of Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to get a bust of his grandfather [Dr. Franklin], of Sèvres China set on a blue stone with a gold border, and send it to him with the bill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires if the "Alliance" will not return to Brest from Nantes to convoy the American vessels. Could then use Dr. Franklin's letter of introduction to Capt. [Pierre] Landais.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding a letter for Dr. Franklin.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives an account of his journey and the vessels he saw in port. Was on board the "Bon Homme Richard." Saw Lady Gransby [?] the renowned English beauty. Asks for news about Miss La Bahard and the Brillon family.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs him to recommend to his grandfather, Mr. Bartholomew Terasson, who went over to America to carry on his trade of merchant; regrets that he is too busy to enjoy his truly interesting conversation or a game of chess.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Called to see him and to remind him that the map of the scene of the war in America made by him (Capitaine) is being engraved. Hopes Dr. Franklin and his son will give it their approbation and send some copies to America.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is leaving for I'Orient and from there will embark for America. Asks William Temple Franklin to write him of his adventures with the "Nymphs of St. Honoré" and other little anecdotes and news of the day. Requests that some clothing he left at the hotel be forwarded to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending a steward; messages from Madame Helvétius and himself.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives an extract of a letter from Capt. Green relating the capture of a convoy of British vessels and supplies bound from New York to Georgia by the "Warren," the "Queen of France" and "Ranger"; Mr. [William] Carmichael to come to France soon in the "Deane." Has also received a letter from La Corogne [Corunna], Spain, giving an account of an engagement between the American privateer "General Arnold" and an English privateer, in which the latter was sunk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Received the case he forwarded and advised M. [Anne César] de la Luzerne; it could not be taken on board the frigate " Du Ploy la Sensible." Will ship it by the "Alliance" or some other vessel.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a copy of the memorial concerning Vandalia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires if Marquis de Lafayette's "intendant" has paid what was due to William Temple Franklin.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received word that his friends in America have collected a considerable sum of money for him and are prepared to honor his drafts. Asks advice as to how he should proceed in the matter. Met Mr. [Sir John] Temple the other evening, he came from Boston by way of Holland.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has heard from a Captain at Bordeaux, who left Hampton, Va., on May 22d, that he saw three of the enemies' ships of war lying at Norfolk but heard nothing of their exploits, as published in the London Gazette. Does not believe they have blocked up a single river.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to his letter to Dr. Franklin about the escaped American prisoners who are in distress at Nantes. Took a particular interest in their cases to counteract the impression there that Dr. Franklin was a cruel, inhuman man, who wantonly left them suffer. S---- has since engaged to pay their landlady out of his own pocket.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing three Loan Office bills for acceptance. Has received a letter from America for John Adams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests that a letter for Sweden which Dr. Franklin promised to write, be sent him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advising him that the ball to be given by Mme. de Merville has been postponed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He will leave, Tuesday, with M. de Samlot, and he expects him to join them.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Heard of his return yesterday. Encloses a letter received from Holland for the Doctor's perusal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notifying him that the King had sanctioned Comte de Vergennes's proposition to allow him to embark at Havre with the French troops bound for England and wear the uniform of Aide-de-camp.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Delighted that he is to be his Aide-de-camp; his rank and uniform; time of embarkation. No news as yet of the situation, manceuvres and intentions of the two fleets. Anxious for some word of Comte d'Estaing. Believes England to be in a bad way. Enclosing a memoir and an address from a Prussian officer, for his grandfather's perusal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is going to settle in business in Bordeaux and enter into partnership with a large exporting firm. Asks to be given the title of Consul for the United States; would perform the duties free.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lloyd, Richard Bennett. Isle of Thanet

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accounts have arrived in London that the French forces have taken Grenada and of an engagement between the French and British fleets. Asks for the address of Mr. [William] Caslon who brought a letter to London from William Temple Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His lodgings will be ready upon his arrival at Havre; hopes for the speedy departure of the expedition.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to get as full particulars as possible at Versailles about the Grenada conquest, as Mr. [Alexander John] Alexander has property interests on that island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received a memorandum of inquiry concerning Henry Dieudonné Drourat. Encloses a letter from him to his father. Chevalier de la Luzerne has not arrived yet, being on his way from Boston. Departure of M. [Conrad Alexandre] Gérard [de Rayneval] universally regretted. Mrs. Bache and himself miss him very much.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He may remain in Paris for some time yet; his presence not being required at Havre. Is himself going to a country seat near Havre. Alludes to the Empress of Russia's efforts to effect a reconciliation between the belligerents. The expedition against England is still being considered by the Ministry, but doubts if it will be decided upon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is anxiously awaiting the arrival of her father's bust; nothing could be more acceptable to her. Has had several letters recently from her brother, William Franklin; always inquires about his father and his son. Is sending a box of squirrel skins to William Temple Franklin by M. [Conrad Alexander] Gérard [de Rayneval]. Requests him to send her several articles which cannot be bought in America and a doll for her young daughter. Asks also that her father send her several household articles. Mentions the Duffield family, the Misses Clifton, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs him to accept a picture of Dr. Franklin which he has ordered.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to some [Loan Office] bills.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Very difficult at present to procure, in America, even the most necessary articles of life and more so curiosities of any kind; tried to get some of the latter for his friends in Paris but without success; money depreciating and merchandise selling at enormous prices. Has heard that his son [Jesse Deane] was spending the holidays with him. Requests the latters to take care of the furniture he left at Passy. Their many enemies and villifiers; every packet brings most outrageous scandal about Dr. Franklin. Is preparing to leave America. Has not seen Mr. [John] Adams since his return; hears he is disgusted at Congress for not appointing him to some Court abroad.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to remind Dr. Franklin to write to England about [Capt. Gustavus] Conyngham who is in prison.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests William Temple Franklin to show his portrait of General Washington to the Marquis Lafayette and let him know the latter's opinion of it; as he wishes to put it on sale and send some copies to America. Hears that M. Lafayette is going to have a full size portrait of General Washington made.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests William Temple Franklin to buy him a watch in Paris. Has left Bordeaux, as he found he could not learn French well there. Is going to put lightning rods on a new house built by neighbor of his; asks a few particulars on the matter.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for the engraving of Washington; thinks it the best likeness he has seen in Europe, with the expection of one in his possession, taken from the original owned by Mr. [John] Hancock; intends to have an engraving made from this, after a drawing by the famous [Charles Nicolas] Cochin. Has received a letter from Capt. [John Paul] Jones in regard to [Capt. Pierre] Landais; regrets disputes between men fighting for the same cause. Begs for American news. Has great hopes of Comte d'Estaing's expedition. In case of embarking, will let him know in due time to get a Havre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for two commissions for the privateers "Black Prince" and "Black Princess." Refers to reported capture of two cutters commanded by [Comte Sutton] de Clonard and de Roquefeuille, off the Lizard.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring about a letter he sent for [Jonathan] Williams, [Jr.], of
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to read his educational plan or program submitted to Dr. Franklin and give his opinion on the English translation of it.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends three letters to be forwarded to Chevalier de la Luzerne, Chevalier D'Anmours and Mr. [John] Bradford. Is uneasy about his baggage and effects which were to be sent him by the latter.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to induce Dr. Franklin to write to Congress about his brother who is serving in the United States.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for various maps of Great Britain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting him to dinner.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Came to France to learn the language and get experience in business. Now knows the language and proposes to go over to America and settle there before the war is over. Asks that his plan be submitted to Dr. Franklin for advice.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking William Temple Franklin to take care of his horse and dispose of him at the first opportunity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Jonathan William [Jr.]'s horse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring about the report of the taking of New York and the defeat of Gen. Prevost by Gen. [Benjamin] Lincoln.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter for M. Suard. Inquires about the order from Congress for goods. Thinks [Le Ray] de Chaumont seems to prefer l'Orient to Nantes for shipping goods, but claims the latter port is more advantageous. Inquires about his new relations [the Alexander family] and [Thomas] Walpole.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is glad to hear Dr. Franklin is recovered. Will call on him Wednesday morning.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring if his letters and some of his maps have been forwarded to the United States as requested.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to send him several "rolls and pots of pomatum."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has learned that William Temple Franklin has been married to one of the Miss Alexanders. Offers his congratulations. Hears that Mr. [Jonathan] Williams, [Jr.], has married into the same family. Wishes to know which of the young ladies is now Mrs. Franklin and which one Mrs. Williams. Encloses a letter to be delivered to Mr. [William] Carmichael as soon as he arrives in Europe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: There are many rumors here about Mr. d'Estaing. He (d'Amchaga) will dine with Mr. Franklin on the 19th.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has heard from Mr. [Jonathan] Williams, [Jr.] that he saw the Captain of the ship "Comité." Latter's account of Comte d'Estaing's movements unreliable. M. [Conrad Alexandre] Gérard [de Rayneval]'s arrival expected to any movement. Has received several letters from his son up to Sept. 18th containing no important news.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is seriously ill and without friends or money. Begs that Dr. Franklin send him a few louis until he can get a remittance from Holland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for any news he has about Capt. [John Paul] Jones and Lieut. Col. [Antoine Félix] Wuibert. Will call on his return to Paris to make arrangements for the coming campaign.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing bills on the Commissioners for acceptance. Inquires about the order for goods from Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers to supply wine.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He is sending him, by way of Amsterdam, a box containing maps ordered by him of counties and towns in England and Ireland.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has heard from M. de Laneuville that some papers have arrived from America for Dr. Franklin. Asks if they contain any news of interest. Inquires about Gen. Washington's health. Is very anxious to hear from M. [Conrad Alexandre] Gérard [de Rayneval].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses bills on the Commissioners. Has heard nothing about the "Confederacy." Fears that she has met with the same fate as poor [Lambert] Wickes in the "Reprisal." Wishes to hear about Congress's orders for goods and his new relations' affairs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses for acceptance twenty-three Continental Loan Office notes drawn on Dr. Franklin. As Congress has ordered his accounts to be paid, hopes some plan will be adopted by Dr. Franklin for making a settlement; his advances having exposed him too much.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for the news about his brother [Normiont de Laneuville] who is serving in the United States. Sent the letter and newspaper containing the article to Marquis Lafayette; has asked the latter to have the letter and article published in the European papers.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing bills on the Commissioners for acceptance. Requests him to reply for Dr. Franklin to his letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks Dr. Franklin and William Temple Franklin for assisting him in need. Remits two louis in payment of the sum loaned to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to procure the release on parole of Geo. Taylor, Lieutenant of the British privateer "Chance," in prison at Bayonne; also of John Craig a passenger on the ship "Matty" of Glasgow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to the wedding of Madamoiselle de Boulainvillers and Le Vicomte de Clermont Tonnere.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know if Mr. [Jonathan] Williams, [Jr.] has returned to
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his letter, will call to see him at the first opportunity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter to Dr. Franklin from Mr. Pollard, and an answer to the letter he dictated for him to the gentlemen at

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending a brave sailor who wishes to obtain a commission from the United States to fit out a privateer and cruise against the English.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses some drafts, bills and gazettes, if these are correct they are to be returned as soon as possible. Tomorrow is the last day for the payment of [John D.] Schweighauser's drafts.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking his protection to obtain a position.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing letters with request that they be forwarded to America.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has heard that General [Aug.ine] Prevost has met the same fate as Burgoyne; if this should not be known at present, he will be discreet.
(In french.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to go to the United States to engage in his trade as printer.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invites him to call on him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Having received a letter from his brother, he decides to remain abroad to wait the results of the West India operations.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his trouble about the horse; has sent some patterns for Dr. Franklin's inspection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses Loan Office bills of exchange for acceptance; the arrival of two Captains from Philadelphia at l'Orient and of a boat from Baltimore at Bordeaux.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to a ball.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The ball has been postponed to Sunday. Asks for news of the arrival of Mr. J[ohn] Adams.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The opinion of Baron de Steding on the conduct of the American soldiers.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for all his trouble and for the condescending goodness of his grandfather; encloses fifteen louis for the watch, which has arrived safely.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests the return of "sundry bills" to him at Nantes; expresses anxiety about the overdue "Confederacy"; no news of Mr. [John] Adams.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepts invitation for dinner and will go with him to the ball.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him to see that M. [Le Ray] de Chaumont pays the bill for the wood.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter for Dr. Franklin, to be presented if proper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a blank privateer commission for Capt. Boardman of the schooner "Betsey," Walter Peter and Co., owners.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Owing to illness, the ball is postponed until the 31st; invites him to dinner on that date.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Considers the Resolve of Congress of Aug. 11, 1778, sufficient authority for the discharge of his claim against the United States; Captain [John] Green lost his vessel through the carelessness of his pilot; offers to take dispatches to America when he leaves with Captain [Thomas] Bell.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests some India rubber for a lady of his acquaintance; regrets that he cannot be with them on Monday.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An invitation to a ball and a dinner on the 7th; also an invitation from some ladies for the 6th.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends his servant for the pass; urges him to write to Dr. [John] P[ringle?] and tells how to send his letter so as to avoid its being opened in London, since ministerial writers are ready to abuse the Doctor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing some bills to be accepted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests a commission or letter of marque for Captain [Samuel] Smith of the "Kensington."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An invitation to dinner.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An invitation to dinner from him and his father; they would also like to have Dr. Franklin.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosed sends a "Catalogue of Characters"; offers to be bearer of any commands for America; sails in the "Luzerne" for Philadelphia; announces the arriaval of the "Caption Jones."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for a pass to Brussels.
A. E. by W[illiam] T[emple] F[ranklin]. Asks if Dr. Franklin will grant this request. By [Benjamin Franklin]. "No."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The arrival of the "Confederacy" ; is anxious for news of Congress; arrangements in the ports of France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introduces William Brush from one of the northern states, and Mr. Wilkinson of South Carolina.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know if Madame Aves has written to him about the ring and pair of shoe buckles, she expected to send him from London.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Glad to know about the false report, that his uncle [John Williams] is in London; he is with him, and in proof sends a letter from him; begs that he destroy this report.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests that the malicious report that he is in London, be denied; he has not been there since Oct. 6th, 1778.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a bill for acceptance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dedicates to him the second edition of his "Choix d'Histoire" and the third of his "Robinson"; encloses; a "Bouts-rimés" for Mlle. de Chaumont.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks the return of the letter from the Marquis Lafayette; thanks him for his zeal in pleading his cause; wishes to obtain the brevet of Lieutenant-Colonel to prove to America that his country was pleased with his conduct.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his recommendation to the school, but decides to place his children near the sea-coast where they will have no opportunity of contracting the Parisian customs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consigned to Messrs. Fizeaux and Grand ninety-six pounds of two line Pica Doric for his grandfather; disappointed he has not received the order for Voltaire's works; has delivered the box to Miss Shipley and sent a letter from her to Dr. Franklin; announces the birth of a daughter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for the return of the papers belonging to Messrs. Sabatie and Depononcy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs to know the first opportunity of sending to London some things which Madame has left.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses, for Dr. Franklin, a copy of the long budget of complaints against Mr. [Silas] Deane and others; denies the truth of these reports.
Enclosure. Extract from the charges against Messrs. Deane, Hodge and Ross.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know if Dr. [Edward] Bancroft has returned and if he could convey a letter to Mr. [Arthur] Lee; invites him and Dr. Franklin to dinner to meet General Bieter and M. Ventades.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclose a bond for a commission for a vessel "owned by A. J. Dornan and fitted in Spain under the auspices of the French Consul at Vigo"; asks for the promised letter for Mr. [John] Aitcheson; has written to Mr. [Le Ray] de Chaumont whose reproaches are injurious.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks to have a certified copy made, at his expense, of his amount lodged with Dr. Franklin as he has sent his only duplicate copy by the "Marquis Lafayette."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sent some squirrel skins by Mr. [Conrad Alexandre] Gérard [de Rayneval]; disappointed at not receiving the bust [of Dr. Franklin]; acknowledges receipt of things from her father; sent to Miss Clifton, before leaving Philadelphia, her most valuable prossessions, among them his little black trunk; the defeat of the enemy at Trenton, made it safe for her to return; the trunk is safe; the Misses Sally and Betsy Duffield have just gone home; Miss [Margaret] Shippen is married to General [Benedict] Arnold.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a small bill from Madrid for acceptance.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An invitation to dinner in the country and a request for passage on the "Alliance" to return to America to serve as a volunteer.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminds him of the service which he rendered him upon his arrival in France; asks him to use his influence to obtain for him the position of correspondent at Morlaix.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for speaking to his father; begs him to write to Captain [John Paul] Jones, and to ask his Excellency for a letter stating that the King is pleased with his services. Declines an invitation to dinner.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He and his family leave soon for America; reports relating to the armament going from Brest to Canada or New York; wishes to know if there is much danger, when he arrives at Sandy Hook, of being obliged to about-ship and go to Halifax or England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The alliance proposed by the Empress of Russia for the protection of the commerce of neutral nations.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends an important package for Mr. [Jean] Holker.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks that Mr. [Francis] Hopkinson's things be sent by Captain [John Paul] Jones. Expects to embark soon under protection of the "Alliance"; offers his services to be useful in any way in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks that Dr. Franklin pay no attention to his last letter. Has obtained permission from M. [Jacques] Necker to transport the woolens, duty free.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: About a Dutch vessel captured by Commodore [John Paul] Jones.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for the loan of his horse, which he sends back to him.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know how much in French money is due him by Mr. [John] Bradford.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for the return of his papers.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends enclosed a letter for Mr. [John Paul] Jones; gives his reasons for not returning to America; the impossibility of securing Mr. [John] Paul Jones for dinner.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introduces his friend Dr. John Foulke.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his kindness in executing Mr. [Francis] Hopkinson's order. Encloses a sheet of his letter paper and tells how to order it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a draft.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know how the remainder of the clothing is to be shipped.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Still waiting for the letters for Mr. [John] Aitcheson; has been managing the European funds of the State of Maryland. Captain Samson of the "Mercury" packet arrived at Plymouth, New England, Feb. 14.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs that Dr. Franklin will make some plan for the purchase of the "Serapis." If Dr. Franklin can devise some plan by whichs to discharge what is due him by the United States, he will buy it. The vessels here are waiting for Captain [John Paul] Jones, to sail under his protection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses bills for acceptance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses two bills for acceptance.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses several bills drawn by Mr. [Francis] Hopkinson on the Commissioners for acceptance.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The frigate "Bonne Voitiere" is blockaded and cannot reach Ranelagh to-day.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He has given a translation to Comte de Vergennes; by order of the Minister he encloses a copy.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses six notes for acceptance drawn by Mr. Fran[cis] Hopkinson on the Commissioners at Paris.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses two notes for acceptance, drawn by Mr. F[rancis] Hopkinson on the Commissioners at Paris.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His father absolutely refuses to give him the means to go to America; if he could receive the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel, he would secure the necessary funds; please renew his proposition to Mr. [John] Paul Jones.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know about the books he asked him to get from England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him to direct some person to secure his negro boy who may have strayed towards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The loss of the negro boy has kept him in Paris, he leaves tonight for I'Orient; should the boy be found after his departure he is to be given to Mr. [John] Adams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for the promised letters from Dr. Franklin.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks that the certified copy of his account be sent by Mr. [John] Ross; wishes to know the truth of the rumor, that the French have been successful against [Admiral] Rodney.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Leaves that night in the "Diligence," asks for the packets and offers to execute any commission "an inch short of high treason." Expects to be back [from England] within three weeks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses notes from Mr. F[ranci]s Hopkinson for acceptance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter for Dr. Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes the name to be put on the medals ordered by Dr. Franklin.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to dinner.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Did not know that the medals were to be of gold, so will bring them all in a short time.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets that he cannot procure the pamphlets; sends other books by Mr. [William] Alexander. He and Mr. [James] Woodmason had lost the order for Voltaire's works, consequently the proprietors will suffer great loss. Miss Shipley will send to Dr. Franklin her father's picture as soon as she finishes it. He met their old master [James] Elphinston who is very poor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know if Mr. [John] Jay is in Paris; confirmation of the news of the taking of the Martinique fleet; other naval news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returns the fencing outfit after making the repairs.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most anxious to reach America; finds all vessels are leaving from l'Orient, so will go there.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks that the enclosed letter be forwarded to [George] Braxton, [Jr.].
In French.
