scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request that he search again for the bills from [Joseph] Gardoqui [Son and Co.].
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Burk regrets that the package for Mrs. H-----y was seized by the Margate Custom House.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets the pleasures of Paris. The "Alliance" has sailed with the fleet. He will leave shortly in a brig which came from Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Leaves in a few days on the "Duke of Leinster" under protection of Captain [John Paul] Jones of the "Ariel"; asks for commissions for America and news of little Benjamin [Franklin] Bache.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks that his library be forwarded to him; the French fleet arrived at Newport; Admiral [Samuel] Graves is at New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes he has been able to complete the Doctor's accounts, gives news of the "Hermione's" encounter with the English off New York and of the capture of " Les Etats d'Artois."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks that he obtain permission for him to enter the French merchant service.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rejoices in having such a sincere friend; any commands he will execute.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been made a Lieutenant-Colonel; now most desirous of returning to America.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announces the death of his cousin Jona[than] Williams; Mr. [Silas] Deane is with him and will leave for Paris in four or five days.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. [Silas] Deane brings this letter and will give all the news; wishes to know Mr. [John] A[dam]s's business in Holland; please get his accounts from Mr. A[dams]. He draws on the Doctor [Franklin] for £1,520 14 s., which has been sent to Mrs. [Richard] Bache, this sum is to come from the Doctor's personal account.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The delay in the sailing of Captain [John Paul] Jones is due to Mr. [Le Ray] de Chaumont who will not pay the wages and prizemoney due the crew.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Having heard that a packet from New London was chased ashore at l'Orient and that the despatches were saved, asks that if there is a letter for him, it be sent in care of Mr. D-----.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His opinion of the morals of the married women of France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses certificates from Mr. [Francis] Hopkinson on the Commissioners.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for the address of a banker, and invites him to visit him at St. Maudé.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells of his lack of success in making love.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter from Messrs. Harmar and Lewis of Philadelphia, concerning some bills. The "Cecil," belonging to Mr. DaCosta, which brought this letter, reports the success of the Americans against [Baron Wilhelm von] Knyphausen and the arrival of the French fleet. Asks his courtesy for Mrs. [William] Blake and her children of South Carolina.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a bill which has passed through several hands without the signature of Mr. [Francis] Hopkinson. Has heard of the great capture by the Spaniards.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hastens to announces [Gen. Sir Henry] Clinton's defeat in Jersey by General Washington.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of American vessels with despatches. The American army is increasing rapidly. Gen. [Horatio] Gates, on his march to Carolina, had collected an army of three thousand before these vessels left. The crew and officers of the vessel detained here have not yet received their wages and prize-money from M. [Le Ray] de Ch[aumont]. His management a mere fizzle and deception.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sees that one of the bills returned has already been paid, sends it back for Mr. [Ferdinand] Grand to see, so as to be able to trace the carelessness or roguery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returns a ticket for a ball.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request that his portrait be sent to him by Captain Sampson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a passport for Mr. Esdaile, a friend.
A.E. by W[illiam] T[emple] F[ranklin]. The passport given.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter to show his knowledge of French.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for the letters and declaring his intention of dining with Dr. Franklin the next day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses the letters to be forwarded to Mr. [George] Braxton, [Jr.].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Capt. [John Paul] Jones has succeeded in getting wages due 45 seamen of the "B[on] H[omme] Richard" on board the " Ariel "; but no prize-money and nothing for those gone to America; Mr. [Samuel] Wharton explains the silence of Captain Jones in this matter is due to desire not to add to his grandfather's troubles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests that a room he secured for him; explains that he could not dine with the Doctor [Franklin] on account of his eyes; asks that the enclosed letters be forwarded to Mr. [George] Fox.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for forwarding his packet from America; his letters contain no news of any importance. Wonders if Mr. [James] Searle has the necessary ability for his commission and what interest can Pennsylvania have separate from the other states. Gives and asks news of Various friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has set sail for America on the "Duke of Leinster"; hopes that Mr. [Joseph] Mayo may see the different amusements of Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introduces Mr. Moore and returns his accounts to have them signed, examined and approved by the Doctor [Franklin].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Describes his life in the country.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As requested sends three packages of seeds of plants unknown in America.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Owing to adverse winds they have not been able to sail. A brig has just arrived from Philadelphia reporting the safe arrival of the "Alliance" [Capt. Pierre] Landais was put under arrest and the "Alliance" was to be offered to Captain [John] Barry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his trouble in enquiring about the lodgings; also for Mr. [George] Fox and Mr. [George] Braxton, [Jr.]'s letters. Accepts his invitation to breakfast.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking him not to bother about the passports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks the address of Mr. [Joseph] Mayo and Dr. [John] Foulke and for Montieu's papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Promises to be more discreet since his letters are subject to examination; acknowledges a letter from [Joseph] Mayo; asks advice about dress; is desirous of hearing the news from America; encloses a letter for [John] Foulke; wishes to know [William] Robeson's plans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses the letters received about sauce pans; recommends Vitel; hopes Dr. Franklin's gout is better.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes the correct news about Gen. [Horatio] Gates's defeat at Camden; the German newspapers are most uncomplimentary; if he receives an answer promptly, he will circulate the correct report.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Besides the squirrel skins sent by Mr. [Conrad Alexandre] Gérard [de Rayneval], eighty odd were sent in a sugar box; sent also a piece of American spun silk to her father; the nuts, apples,and cotton shall be sent shortly in a twenty-gun ship; supposes he has heard about [Benedict] Arnold; gives news of her children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Great desire to know the true story of [Gen. Horatio] Gates's defeat. Wishes to know of any vessel sailing for his port as he has letters to send.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for his letter and the extract from the Pennsylvania Gazette; when the information about Gen. [Horatio] Gates is received, he requests that it be sent to him as soon as possible.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Apologizes for not inquiring personally about his Excellency; would like to know when he will be able to see him.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Anxiety about his Excellency's health; has not yet received any papers or power to administer the oath of allegiance; advises that the public dispatches be sent as soon as possible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for a permit to ship arms and war-like stores on the "Mars."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request that the eleven letters of exchange be sent to him as soon as possible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks that his accounts be examined and that he certifies that they are like the original in the possession of his Excellency [Dr. Franklin].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his letter; hopes his Excellency's health will be soon restored; has been ill himself but hopes soon to sail with Captain [John Paul] Jones.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends back the commission for Captain Boardman, requesting the bond to be destroyed; asks for a commission for Captain James Byrnes, enclosing a bond already signed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Glad to hear of his Excellency's recovery; finds it exceedingly dull in the Capital of the reign of Mammon; request for news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter received from The Hague; hopes there is not reason for the anxiety expressed in it; requests to hear news received by the frigate "Amazone."
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has had a very disagreeable time. His friends, Trumble, remains in prison; requests that letters for them be sent to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses notes drawn by F[rancis] Hopkinson for acceptance.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An invitation to dinner.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The English are not permitted to enter Spain, where he is most anxious to go to perfect his Spanish, therefore he could only go as an American. If it is possible he would like Dr. Franklin to give him a certificate or passport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complains that she has not received any letters for a twelve month; gives news of the family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his good news; the Emperor [Joseph II] is friendly to France; the English have declared war against Holland.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends all the certificates properly signed; he received the rank of Brigadier-General as a reward for his talents; requests that the papers be returned as soon as possible.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending a lackey.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He leaves Saturday for St. Florentin; offers to do any commissions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him to go with him to a ball where pretty women will be as thick as hops.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An invitation to a ball.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks that the enclosed letters be given to Dr. Franklin to forward.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Urging him to come to them, promises him dancing.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The ball was postponed on account of an epidemic of colds, called follette. Hopes Franklin can come.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires what was the value of a dollar in May, 1779; will send his American papers to be certified by Dr. Franklin; M. [Peter Charles] L'Enfant is about to leave.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for news; has received letters from Brest giving size of merchant fleet ready to sail.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The enclosure is for his Excellency [Dr. Franklin]; asks his protection to obtain a command as Captain on a French merchantman. Wishes to know if Mr. [Samuel] Wharton, of Philadelphia, has left

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for his great-coat and spurs left at Passy by Mr. [Jonathan] Williams. [Jr.].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending twelve bottles of malmsey from Madeira.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will not leave until next Friday; invites him to dine with him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The long piece of writing for Mr. Wharton's father, which requires to be finished immediately, deprives him of the pleasure he should take in rendering Mr. Fevery service.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses bills for acceptance; William Temple Franklin writes that Captain [Samuel] Smith will get his command; wishes to know about Captain Boardman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing bills for acceptance.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him and Dr. Franklin for the latter's letter of recommendation, which had a good effect on the Ministers at Versailles.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to bronzing his buckels.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending several drafts on Dr. Franklin for M. de Montaudouin.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cannot dine with him, as [Pierre Aug.in Caron de] Beaumarchais has requested him to be at home at 4 o'clock.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for news about the situation in America. The hand bill a fabrication to frighten [Gen. Sir Henry] Clinton, [Gen. Lord] Cornwallis and [Gen. Alexander] Leslie. Is obliged to him for form of bill book and explanation as to how to use it. The States Generals have resolved to grant letters of marque. Alludes to the threatened coalition of European powers against England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests that a parcel of bills be delivered to M. [Ferdinand] Grand. Directions about shipment of his printing press.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to Harmar and Lewis's Loan Office Bills. Alludes to his wife's recent serious illness and to Le Ray de Chaumont's business failure.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to reports from The Hague and declaration of war by England against the Dutch Republic. Will have to go to Versailles to see the new Minister. Sends items of news received from Toulon about launching of new warships.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to an entertainment and dance at M. Dufay's.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to give the bearer information about trade in America.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending drafts by [Francis] Hopkinson on Dr. Franklin. Alludes to his wife's critical illness.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plan for equipping a vessel, for which Dr. Franklin had given a passport, had to be abandoned owing to insecurity of remaining in London. Passport had to be destroyed to avoid detection. Requests that the bond deposited with Dr. Franklin be cancelled.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has written to M. [Jacques] Necker; cannot unload his ship until he receives a reply. Cannot procure freight for Capt. [Joseph] Conkling's vessel, [the "Whim"] at Rochelle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to Jonathan Williams's accounts with Le Ray de Chaumont.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending bills for acceptance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is in I'Orient to attend to Jonathan Williams's interests in the loading of the ship "Marquis Lafayette." Sends bills by [Francis] Hopkinson on the Commissioners.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending copy of letter from M. de Fontenet about the Comtesse de Forbach's illness.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Giving directions about the shipment of his printing machine and refers to the case of a "poor fellow" he is interested in.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells of condition of Comtesse de Forbach, who is ill. Inquires about reported desertions from Gen. Washington's army.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending bills on the Commissioners for acceptance.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to a dance at M. Dufay's.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Croix, Mr. and Mme. de Stante

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting him to a dance at their house.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending particulars of Comtesse de Forbach's illness; her recovery expected.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to Comtesse de Forbach's illness.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a bill for acceptance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complains of the lack of courtesy and insolence of the Captain of the "Marquis Lafayette" to his passengers. Fears they will have an unpleasant voyage. Refers to Mlle. Brillon and Mlle. Sophie [de] Perceval.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is anxious to become an American citizen, but not prepared to go through the formalities at Bordeaux. Intends to go to Madrid first to learn Spanish. Asks his opinion and advice in the matter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was prevented by a severe illness from writing to his family and friends in America for a long time. Requests him to send word to his friends at Philadelphia of his recovery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to letters to be forwarded to Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received a letter from Le Ray de Chaumont, Sr., which had a good effect on the Captain. Encloses a letter for de Chaumont fils.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending papers to be certified by Dr. Franklin relative to an account which he is to collect in the United States.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cannot finish making his shirts on account of her health. Requests him to send for them.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets that [Le Ray] de Chaumont has such a good opinion of his Captain who is very unpopular. Refers to Mlles. Brillon, Mme. Caillot and Mlle. [Sophie] de P(erceval). Encloses a letter for de Chaumont fils.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a copy of his previous letter about his project of going to Madrid for a few months before setting out for America, and requests an early reply.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is just setting out from Nantes. Inquires if two bills endorsed by Nat[haniel] Barrett have been paid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sails to-day on the "Marquis Lafayette" for Philadelphia, under escort of the "Alliance," with six or seven American vessels.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Blame Samuel Wharton for their embarrassing situation owing to lack of ready money. Ask if Dr. Franklin will help them to procure some cash on good security.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On his return finds $400 missing. Hopes prudent measures will be taken to discover the culprit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: State of public affairs in America. Party spirit and jealousy still prevail. The Southern army under [Gen. Nathanael] Greene in a much better situation since the action with [Gen. Lord] Cornwallis. Requests for sets of crayons to be sent him by Capt. Darby of the ship "Hope."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to purchase for Mrs. Jay several articles of dress, etc., and send them by his courier to Madrid. Remarks on the subject of dress and equipage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to purchase several articles for Mrs. [John] Jay and himself.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending drafts for acceptance.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires about the departure of a vessel for Philadelphia; wishes to write to his friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is preparing to leave Bordeaux; expects to travel with Col. [Henry Brockholst] Livingston from Bayonne to Madrid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires about articles which Dr. Franklin wishes to ship to Mrs. [Jane] Mecom.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. [John] Jay's courier returned from Paris with letters and articles purchased for them. Thanks him for his trouble. Expresses his gratitude for Dr. Franklin's friendship.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has heard of the arrival of the ship "Mars" at Boston. Articles for Mrs. [Jane] Mecom will be shipped by the "Active." Refers to American seamen deserting from the "Marquis Lafayette."
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is uneasy at not receiving any replies to his letters. Has not heard from either [Joseph] Mayo or [John] Foulke.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just returned from Champlost. Encloses a letter to be forwarded to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Winslow Warren from Massachusetts.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets he cannot postpone the dinner; Mr. [John] Laurens will be present.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is pleased with the articles purchased for him and Mrs. Jay. Requests him to send Mrs. Jay a pair of shoe buckles and to forward letters brought by Col. [John] Laurens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is leaving on his annual tour of inspection. Requests that any important news received from America be communicated to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects to arrive at St. Germain on the 10th. The ladies of Passy mistaken in saying he has not "common sense"; is bringing it with him.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is happy to learn that Col. [Banastre] Tarleton has been defeated; has heard a report of the capture of Gen. [Benedict] Arnold. Wishes to know what the French and the allies in general are doing now.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs him to let her know why he no longer recommends her boarding school, and does not send her any more boarders.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report that M. [Jacques] Necker is out of place; every one seems to regret it. Inquires if Mr. [Charles] Thomson, Secretary to Congress, has a nephew in France. Heard of a young man claiming to be such who had gone into Spain. Refers to [John] Foulke and [Joseph] Mayo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Intends to go to America soon. Asks if he could go in some convoy or in any of the French warships or frigates. Refers to the coming abundant vintage. The people generally dissatisfied with the dismissal of [Jacques] Necker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dr. Franklin's will was committed to her father's care, when in America; is with the latter's papers in a trunk at New York; otherwise it would have been returned as requested.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mrs. [John] Jay satisfied with reasons for having a watch made for her. Has left 50 louis in Dr. Franklin's hands to pay for purchases made for them in Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Received by Mr. Faber articles purchased for him. Intends to buy in France what articles he may need, as they are much cheaper than in Spain. Wishes to draw on Dr. Franklin for his salary as it becomes due. Mentions reports of the movements of the belligerent fleets. Abbé Alvarez and Mr. Faber appear warm friends of Dr. Franklin and his grandson. Requests the latter to present his compliments to Princess Masseran and the Marquise Lafayette. Hears Dr. Franklin has written some little pieces lately; is very desirous to get them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The letter to Mme. [Jean] Holker was delivered to her personally. Thinks the Williams who claims to be a nephew of Dr. Franklin is an impostor; heard of him being in a hotel at Havre; will endeavor to stop the imposition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring about the business reputation of Mr. [James] Moylan, of l'Orient.
In French.
A.E. Mr. [James] Moylan no longer associated with ------- Gourlade, refers Henry Grand to ------ Pothonnier, banker.
(In French. Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informs him that the brig "Lord Charlemont" sailed for America with his property on the 13th. Hopes to be able to follow with his family in a few months. People of Ireland now convinced of the treachery and deceit of England; their trade and commerce get no protection from the British Government. Thinks now is the time for France and the United States to strike a crushing blow at England by helping Ireland to secure her independence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cannot procure the seeds from [William] Bartram until Autumn. The "Alliance" and her convoy have not appeared yet. Fears that the "Shellala," Capt. Holmes, has foundered at sea. Knew several passengers on board; John Benezet being amongst the number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is alarmed at [Joseph] Mayo's condition of health. Thinks he should leave Paris. Refers to Dr. Franklin and his grandson's escape from the opera house.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will pay M. Le Veillard [fils] every attention as soon as he arrives. Inquires about M. [Conrad Alexandre] Gérard [de Rayneval]. The bust [of Dr. Franklin] did not arrive in the "Alliance" or the "Ariel." Will send the squirrel skins as soon as she can procure them. Requests that some fine green tea be sent to her. Miss Duffield to marry a Mr. Hepburn. Encloses a print of songs sung at an "oratorical entertainment" at the [French] Minister's [Anne César de la Luzerne]. Have had entertainments on the "Hermione" and in "Don Francisco's Garden."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a letter by Mr. G[eorge] Harrison who is going to France, to be delivered to his brother [George Fox].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to get information for a relative at Amiens, who wishes to establish business relations in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Saw Mr. Small who spoke highly of him; wishes he was serving "his own king and country." Tells of his former friends, "Sandy," Miss. Marcy, Mammy Thackwell, Sam Johnson, etc. Has not seen Mrs. [Margaret] Stevenson for a long time.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Barber who is going to Paris with reference to a claim against the authorities at St. Domingo for property unjustly detained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just recovered from a dangerous illness. Sends his work "Memoirs of the Court of Aug.us," 2d edition.
In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has not heard from [Joseph] Mayo or [John] Foulke or any of his friends in Paris for a long time. Refers jestingly to Foulke's assiduity in visiting the "bald head and tail Countess."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The two or three small bills of exchange on [Le Ray] de Chaumont have given him much trouble. Received cash for one and now needs the amount of the others, but cannot get them cashed. Will cause him great inconvenience.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for the Madeira he sent him during his convalescence.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends her letter by Mrs. McCarty whom his grandfather was well acquainted with in Canada. Mrs. [Dorcas] Montgomery is going in the same vessel, but she is not on good terms with her now. Old Dr. [William] Shippen has just called with a letter for Dr. Franklin; tells a wonderful story about his son's house being struck by lightning. Mr. Bryson is still in the postoffice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is on board the Continental brig "Active," which came from Nantes to sail with the convoy bound for the West Indies. Three warships and a cutter are with the convoy. A signal has just been put out for the fleet to get ready to sail.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Samuel Griffitts who is going to Europe to prosecute his studies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has only been able to obtain the book this morning, sends it by a messenger. Mr. [Ferdinand] Grand wants to know the fate of Messers Parish and Thomson's bills.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses bill of exchange drawn on Le Ray de Chaumont for 1,500 livres. Has received 949 livres on account.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His trip yesterday and kind reception by Dr. Franklin and his grandson have considerably hastened his return to health.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is ready to pay what [Jonathan Loring?] Austin owes Dr. Franklin. Inquires if any new orders for clothing are to be given by Congress, to replace those lost on the "Marquis Lafayette."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending a young man who seeks to be employed by him.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just arrived at his destination after a very long voyage from Paris. Heard reports in the English islands about battles in which the Americans were defeated; does not credit such reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to buy him some paper and send recipe for making ink.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has decided to start for Holland soon after he arrives at Paris. Refers to [Joseph] Mayo and [John] Foulke.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a package of bills for acceptance. Capt. [John] Folger, who visited Passy recently, regarded in America as a Tory. Refers to rumors of approaching peace and begs to be given a hint in time. Has received letters from Aunt [Jane] Mecom and Mr. [Richard] Bache.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will be glad to see Mr. Young if he comes to Nantes and will do all he can for him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to ask M. [Ferdinand] Grand to advance him 100 pounds; will repay as soon as he receives a letter from

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returning Capt. Collyer's bond and enclosing bills on the Commissioners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a passport for Joseph HIll Jennings, who is going from Nantes into Spain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends copies of two letters received from a house at Cape San Domingo relating to the circumstances of the seizure of the ship "Diamond" with cargo of slaves and dry goods. Claims the seizure was illegal and has entered a protest at Paris against it.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is translating enclosures contained in his letter into Spanish. Occupies a pavillion of the house in which the Prince of Masseran lived last year; is pleased to hear of the Princess's remembrance of him. Is on a friendly footing with all the foreign Secretaries. Knew Mr. [John] Adams's visit to Paris was on account of the proposed conferences for peace; is not surprised at his silence towards Dr. Franklin. Deplores the jealousy displayed by the American envoys towards each other and their lack of cooperation. If Comte de Grasse has a favorable passage, a blow may be struck at the headquarters of toryism in America. No news of the Duke de Crillon's arrival at Minorca. Desires a seal ring to be purchased for him with the head of Brutus, Socrates or Dr. Franklin on it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Learns that the clothing and arms for the army are to be furnished by the (French) Government; does not except any part in it. Twice contributed 50 guineas anonymously to Mrs. Johnson's support after the Barbadoes calamity; shall take care that she does not suffer, but does not wish to be known in the matter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a letter received from Mr. [Samuel] Hartley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter to M. [Jean François Joly] de Fleury; if endorsed by Dr. Franklin, thinks it will procure him part of the new order for supplies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests return of bills left in his care.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Can only correspond with Le Ray de Chaumont about the matters in question. Tells of Mr. [Richard] Bache being nearly killed by a thrust from a cow's horn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for a letter which Capt. [William] Robeson left with Dr. Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is surprised at the arrival and request of W. Montague, the young African. Intends, as promised, to set him up as a barber in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes he has received a letter from his partner and nephew who sailed in the brig "Lord Charlemont." Proposes sending another vessel soon to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests that a passport be procured for him from Comte de Vergennes, to go to the South of France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Incloses letters to be forwarded to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires how much an acre of ground in North America is equivalent to in French measurements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to young Montague, his colored servant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is leaving for Orleans and his son [Samuel Cooper Johonnot] for Geneva. Requests a few lines of introduction to Mr. [Jonathan] Williams, [Jr.], and other merchants of

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introduces Major [David Salisbury] Franks and requests that he be shown particular attention; is well and favorably known throughout the Union and could counteract the work of their common personal enemies at home. Refers to A[rthur] L[ee] as one of the bitterest and alludes to his ambition to become Secretary of Foreign Affairs. Dr. Franklin has now the same commission as Mr. [John] Adams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Major David [Salisbury] Franks whose mission to Europe is known to him. Saw a lightning conductor upon a powder magazine at Segovia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives an account of his journey through Holland and part of Germany. Is racked and fatigued after a long and arduous journey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is about to set out for Nantes; offers to take any letters or messages for that place.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Latest events of the war. [Gen.Lord] Cornwallis besieged at Yorktown by land and sea; the English fleet returned to New York badly battered; report of a bloody battle in South Carolina between Gen. [Nathanael] Greene's army and the British.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Hopkins and Mr. Gibbs, who are going to France. Gives an account of a battle in South Carolina between Gen. Greene and the English troops.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to purchase and send her by Major [David Salisbury] Franks, two pairs of paste shoe buckles, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Replies to inquiry about Philip Dieffenbach and the Mengs family. Will forward seeds as soon as Mr. [William] Bartram puts them up. Request civilities for Capt. Hoops a American officer and a brother of Mrs. [Thomas] Barclay, who was taken prisoner at the battle of Camden and is going to Europe on a furlough.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Capt. Hoops, brother-in-law of Mr. [Thomas] Barclay recently appointed Consul General to France, who is going to France with his sister.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Preparing a celebration for his mother's feast day. Would like to get some verses from M. [Amé Ambroise Joseph] Feutry for the occasion. Invities William Temple Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Relating to endorsement of his bills by Dr. Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Have had many festivities in honor of the French troops. Considers them a fine body of men.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expressing thanks to Abbé Arnoux and his friend M. Jaume, of Lyons, for their attentions to his son [Samuel Cooper Johonnot].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the receipt of Dr. Franklin's bounty to Mrs. Johnson. Delivered book and letter to Mr. Small. References to Mrs. Thackwell and Miss Marcey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Relating to the repayment of 25 guineas loaned to him by Dr. Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepts Dr. Franklin's approval of his application to M. [Jean François Joly] de Fleury to furnish supplies. Has no funds belonging to Capt. [William] R[obeson] who is considerably in his debt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to call at the office of the "Gazette de France" and get several copies of the paper containing an account of the victory over [Gen. Lord] Cornwallis, which Dr. Franklin wishes to send to Madrid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Are greatly disappointed at not being able to obtain advances of money, as they have considerable property in America. Are in a very unpleasant situation owing to Mr. [Samuel] Wharton's ingratitude. Enclose a letter for Mr. Carson, their attorney at Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Promises to remit money due him and Mr. Raymond.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter from his brother, which he wishes to have certified by Dr. Franklin.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Have had to stop on their journey to Brussels, owing to excessive fatigue. Have not been in bed since they left Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reached Brussels last night in company with [George] Fox; Fox has set out for Amsterdam. Expects to receive letters and bills of exchange from America soon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter for Abbé de la Roche and one from Capt. [John] Kinnier, an Engliish prisoner at Ancenis, who begs to be exchanged with his crew for American prisoners in England. Capt. [Gustavus] Cun[n]ingham has had an offer of a 30-gun French frigate, but will not accept without an American commission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives an account of their hunting expeditions. Request to buy him several articles in Paris.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting that the copy of Dr. Franklin's letter to his brother be returned to him.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him two game licenses.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: May have to wait several months before he can get passage on a vessel for America. Hears that part of the fleet at Brest will sail for America; asks if he may go to Brest to await orders. Refers to the de Chaumont and Mme. de Deux-Ponts families.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells of his arrival and of delivering despatches to Mr. [John] Adams. His first impression of the people of Holland, the climate, etc., most unfavorable. Refers to [Joseph] Mayo, [John] Foulke, and [George] Harrison.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Knox, William. On board "L'Engageant," Road of Groia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter with request that it be forwarded to destination.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a copy of the letter written to Silas Deane with reference to the sale of his Loan Office certificates. Requests return of his power of attorney given to Silas Deane.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Hoops, a young American officer who is a prisoner to the English but who is on furlough.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses letter from a Scotch Captain, a prisoner of war, about his exchange. Promises to repay Dr. Franklin the 25 louis he owes him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to interest himself in Mr. [John] Shee's affair. Has procured the seeds from Mr. [William] Bartram and has shipped two boxes of them on the brig "Bets[e]y."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends copy of a letter from Capt. [John] Cochran, of Philadelphia, relating to payment of his son's tuition in a school at Paris.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Collections of New York Historical Society, 1889. Deane Papers, IV, 541.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends invitation from Mme. Droin; M. Grand to be of the party.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fears he may become stupid owing to the depressing effect of the climate. [Joseph] Mayo finds Brussels more agreeable. Has not yet presented his letter of introduction to M. Grand de La Chaise. Remarks on Cornwallis's surrender.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to purchase three kegs of powder for him at the Arsenal. Tells of another accident in which he was nearly killed.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Relating to shipment of boxes of seeds and pippin grafts; cannot procure squirrel skins. Asks his opinion as to the effect of Cornwallis's surrender.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks for the copy of Count de Vergennes's letter narrating the surrender of Cornwallis. Tells of a person having lately seen and conversed with Mr. [Henry] Laurens in the Tower of London; implies he has been treated with severity and rigor. [George] Fox's opinion of the Dutchmen's hospitality. Likes Brussels but finds the climate too damp.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Improved conditions in the country in general. The assistance of France very valuable to the United States. The lack of economy and squandering of the public funds caused much want and distress in the beginning. The Marquis Lafayette has set out for Boston to embark for France. Silas Deane's recently published letter has caused surprise and resentment against him; his strictures on the vanity and folly of some Americans in Europe very often justified.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returning draft for £2,000 accepted by them.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The arrival of Mr. [Thomas] Barclay will relive Dr. Franklin from much trouble. Rejoicings over the birth of the Dauphin and the success of the allied armies in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Great rejoicing amongst the Americans on receipt of news telling of the surrender of Cornwallis. Thinks if Charlestown and New York were retaken it would end the war. Inquires if the "St. James", from Philadelphia, brings news of any material changes in that city.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expressing his thanks for Mme. H ----'s letter forwarded to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fears that his prolonged stay, waiting for a vessel, will be very expensive to the Government at home. The number of people arrived with the Franch fleets of war have caused a scarcity of necessaries of life; prices are very high. The "St. James," Capt. [Thomas] Truxton, probably the first vessel which will sail for America about Jan. 15. His situation very unpleasant and embarrassing. Was arrested the other day on suspicion of being a spy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was obliged to leave Madrid and come to Cadiz on account of his health. Intends soon to embark for America; will make his head-quarters at Philadelphia. Comments on Cornwallis's surrender and its effect on England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to Major [David Salisbury] Franks and to M. Montfort whom Silas Deane has urged him to employ in his counting house. Asks what are Thomas Barclay's intentions regarding Consuls in different ports. Requests to be kept posted on the trend to events, as it is a critical time for American trade. Encloses letter from M. [Andrew] Limozin of Havre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Relating to payment of Loan Office certificates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Do not know anything about the 400 pounds of indigo referred to by Mr. Cochran, as having passed through Col. [John] Laurens's hands. The latter alone can clear up the matter.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Dr. Dexter who is going to Paris with Thomas and Joseph Winthrop and Dr. Parker. Has forwarded the Journal of Congress for 1778 to Dr. Franklin. Refers to Mr. [George] Fox as a very worthy character.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends samples of velvet for Dr. Franklin's costume.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to young Cochran's embarrassing situation. Is surprised that Mr. [Thomas] Barclay has no orders from Congress for settling its public accounts in Europe.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Collection of New York Historical Society, 1889, Deane Papers, IV, 554.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With great difficulty, got a pass for Capt. Smedley to go to l'Orient to embark in the " St. James." Complains that the authorities at Brest are not friendly towards Americans; has been treated with suspicion. Inquires about Count William de Deux-Ponts; mentions "the lovely Countess and Lady Nicholson.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives the address of Bertrand from whom he bought his sword and recomends him as an honest man.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to reply to M. [Andrew] Limozin's application for Consulate at Havre. Speaks of the Captain's [William Robeson] indebtedness to them both. Is about to send two fine Cheshire cheeses and a few boxes of tea for Dr. Franklin and Abbé Morellet. Has bought some fine old Madeira wine recently and will send half a pipe to the Doctor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know where she can get the benches like those used for his fête.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will lend him his riding horse.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The vessel is ready to start; the medallion of Dr. Franklin is on board, he hopes the English will not capture it; since he last wrote he made a little trip to Dinan, St. Malo, etc.; at Cancale he saw the two frigates burnt. The country is in a sad state, with its commerce ruined.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to dinner.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Deux-Ponts, Marianne Camasse, duchesse La douairière de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is alarmed at reports about Dr. Franklin's health. Sends a package to be forwarded to her son [Guillaume Comte de Deux-Ponts] in America.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for his inquiries about his health; will call on him soon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks that the passports from the Comte de Vergennes be given to the bearer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for procuring the apartment in Paris; Captain [William] Robeson's letter will receive great care; accepts the invitation for dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Having recovered from his illness, he will take possession of the room he offers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends his servant to Dr. Franklin's house for some clothing he left there.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter to be sent to Mr. [William] Alexander; asks for a settlement of Dr. Franklin's account; Mr. [Francis M.] Dana wishes a new credit; returns Robert Morris's bill which will be sent back unless Dr. Franklin orders differently.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending in account to be signed by Dr. Franklin.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for the ticket; will do what he desires about the horse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets that business prevents his accompanying him to Mr. [Ferdinand] Grand's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for estimates of articles ordered by the Board of War with prices affixed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for a copy of the Resolves of Congress for 1778.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Declines an invitation for dinner; has received the books from the binders; asks that the package be brought when the books are called for.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him not to write to M. [Jacques] Turgot; officers to bring the remainder of the pamphlets; will dine with him and his grandfather Wednesday evening.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An invitation for him and Dr. Franklin to dine at his house with Madame. Helvétius; thanks for the cheeses and tea.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks about Dr. Franklin's health; gives the address of a painter.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for the loan of fifteen guineas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Called on Dr. Franklin with the intention of giving him an order on M. Grand for the fifteen guineas which he was so obliging as to lend him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Making arrangements for taking G[urdon] S. Mumford into his counting house; asks to be kept informed of the motions of Mr. [Matthew] Ridley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Giving the names of vessels by which boxes of seeds have been sent. Have inoculated their youngest child, Debby, and she has got through the small-pox finely.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Signifies his willingness to give security for Captain Angus.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In return for executing his commissions for maps, etc., asks for American news. Offers his services to Mr. [William] C[a]rm[ichae]l.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Denies authorship of a letter attributed to him, written to the Journal de Paris, concerning the Anatomical Cabinet of M. [Jean Joseph] Sue, of which he encloses a copy (2p.).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for the present address of W[illia]m Knox, of Boston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning two American prisoners in Havre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to his "nymph" and the Court festivals at the "Muette." Tells how he spends his time in the country. Has not received any word from [Samuel] Wharton about the goods he consigned to him.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects to leave Gand tomorrow for Bruges and Ostend.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Major Porter who has a furlough from Gen. Washington to spend a few months in Europe. He (Franks) will sail in a day or two.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Suspects that his father opened the letter addressed to him by his "lady love" and wishes to prevent his return to Paris. Thinks of leaving surreptitiously and passing a night in Paris and then returning.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives an account of his pleasure in Geneva.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a draft made in favor of Dr. Franklin; thanks for sums advanced.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: About to leave Paris for Amsterdam. Asks for passport, if one is necessary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A request to forward letters to his brother-in-law, Richard Bennett Lloyd, in Maryland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Would like to have his opinion on his experiments with seals for letters. Hears that young Le Veillard is going to Bordeaux; invites him to stop at Chaumont.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Spent last week with Mr. [Silas] Deane at Ghent. Proposed coming directly to Paris so took charge of the enclosed packet for Dr. [Edward] Bancroft, which may contain letters of cousequence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Making an appointment to dine with Mme. Helvétius at William Temple Franklin's.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for the return of the memoir addressed to the Duc de Panthever.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for having obliged her.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses drafts for Dr. Franklin's signature. List of articles sent Mrs. [Jane] Mecom, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Opposition in English Parliament to continuing the war. Other news items. His view of Marquis Lafayette's motive in espousing the cuase of the American Colonies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explains the cause of his failure to recover the money he [Franklin] lent Captain [William] Robeson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On the eve of embarking for America, gratefully acknowledges kindly sentiments expressed in letters from Dr. [Joseph] Priestley, Dr. [Richard] Price, Dr. Franklin, Mr. [John] Jay and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges attentions received and requests that letters for him be forwarded to

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deplores the loss of a friend.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: [Capt. William] Robeson has been given command of a vessel Mr. [Jonathan] Williams, [Jr.] and others have purchased. Hopes he will now be able to collect the money he owes him [Franklin].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. Donmartin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He will send to Mr. Carpenter, the package for Madame Hervey.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Captain Donmartin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends two boxes of seeds.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks to set a time when he can take leave, etc.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for a blank warrant which he can fill in with his son's name, to secure the latter's advancement in the American navy. He is baptised Josiah Williams, and is now in his sixth year. Mentions the popular desire in England for peace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Promises to pay the twenty louis when the expected bill of exchange arrives; another promissory note of an earlier date subjoined.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to supper to hear Volange and Boyer [two celebrated artists].
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks that his letters be forwarded.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives an amusing account of his own love affairs. Inquires about the safety of William Temple Franklin's cousin [Benjamin Franklin Bache] in Geneva. Card-playing the most popular and only amusement in Bordeaux.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for paper and ink for his press. Was told that Dr. Franklin had given Letters of Marque against the Portuguese, thinks it false, but if it is so requests Letters of Marque for his vessel, the "Spry."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has heard doubt of the solidity of Mr. [Ferdinand] G[ran]d. Does not believe it, but cannot conceal this from him. Begs him to look after Dr. Franklin's interests. Hears rumors of an American war with Portugal. If there is anything in them, do not forget his Letter of Marque for the "Spry."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends twenty-four setts of exchanges for acceptance. Repeats rumor of war with Portugal and his desire that the "Spry" should be commissioned to take Portuguese ships.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a bill neglected to be included in a packed sent the same day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning money due from [Capt. William] Robeson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His arrival in Philadelphia after having been detained as a prisoner on the Quebec frigate, and then paroled; a splendid entertainment given by Congress in honor of the Dauphin; surprised and alarmed at the prevalence of French fashions and luxury instead of the republican simplicity he had expected to find.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: [Capt. William] Robeson's indebtedness. The latter's negro boy, Montagu[e], ran away last night; should he hear of him requests that he secure him until he hears from Mr. [Jonathan] Williams, [Jr.] or himself.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Source of rumors regarding Mr. [Ferdinand] G[rand], but does not credit them. Repeats request for a reply to his letter regarding the prisoners, who are being boarded at his expense.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses sixty-two bills to exchange on the Commissioners, for acceptance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A letter of thanks and appreciation for courtesies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. E. Thompson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges the receipt of books sent from London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expressing anxiety about his despatches for America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expressing thanks for political hints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Repeats circumstance of detention on board the Quebec frigate, and his subsequent parole; gives an account of an execution by refugees and steps taken by General Washington to revenge the same. Other personal matters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him to procure Dr. Franklin's signature to letters protesting his innocence of having sent ammunition to America for the use of the English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes he received the three boxes of seeds he sent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Disturbances in Switzerland cause him to change his traveling plans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has money for Captains Durfy and Hains, who were in Mill Prison but said to be now exchanged; wants to know how to transmit it to them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter for Mr. [John] Jay. If he receives an unpropitious answer to his last letter to William Temple Franklin he will take passage on the "Nonesuch" for Philadelphia; offers to take letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received a commission to engrave a portrait of Marquis Lafayette, and reminds him of his promise to ask Madame la Marquise for the loan of the portrait which is on his snuff box.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regarding prisoners escaped from England who demand support.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Business announcement.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering services to take commissions to

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests that Dr. Franklin will attest a power of attorney.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In behalf of M. Fisson, of Malaga, who wishes to be appointed Consul.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. [Gabriel] Tardy, Mr. [Jonathan] Williams, [Jr.]'s head clerk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for a permit to be allowed to reside some time in Boulogne for his health.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Describes a visit to Rome.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advising of the shipment of wines and price of same.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recounting the circumstance of his unjust detention and requests the intervention of Benjamin Franklin. Account of how he came there.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to forward the enclosure.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting magazines and English newspapers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for a copy of the trio composed by Madame Brillon; that the enclosed questions be given to Dr. Franklin and that he answers them as quickly as possible for Madame la Maréchale de Beauveaux who wishes to put a lightning rod on her castle.
In French.
Enclosure. The answer to the questions, by Benjamin Franklin. 2p.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applies for a credit with Dr. Franklin. Is about to leave Paris for London where he thinks he can do more good.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests that a passport be made out for him to go to Dieppe and from there to London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes him to remind his grandfather to give him a letter of recommendation to M. [Jean Pierre] David, physician.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting him and friends, to see his collection.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: MacMahon, John. At the Military school in Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remedies to be taken to cure eruptions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to have mail forwarded.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells of his extensive law practice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Suggests that released prisoners of war on their way from England to Nantes be recommended to him, as he understands English and can prevent their being imposed upon.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Describing his travels, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Making an appointment to receive him.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Renewing his invitation to dinner.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Declines to take a clerk into his employ.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring about missing letter and packets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has made inquiries regarding Dr. Franklin's case and encloses opinion of W. Lisle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Making friendly inquiries regarding Dr. Franklin's welfare, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Dr. Franklin's signature to a money order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning style and price of a wooden bowl he had ordered.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Apologizes for not having returned his great-coat sooner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received [Tiberius] Cavallo's book [on the "Nature and Properties of Air"] from London; the plates to be sent to the Philadelphia Library. [Joseph] Priestley's last volume and other books of Dr. Franklin.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks for arranging his visit to M. Bertin's cabinet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for a letter authorizing the release of goods from the custom house at Calais.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for letter of marque of ship "Nancy" commanded by Capt. William Burlingham.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for subscription in aid of Captain Hardy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a letter a Marquis de Castries with information of his (Barclay's) appointment by Congress to settle for prize-money arising from the cruise of Commodore [John] Paul Jones.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs him to arrange an interview with Dr. Franklin.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His love affairs and conquests. Advises William Temple Franklin to beware of the Italian damsels. Remarks on the disaster to the "Royal George." Inquires about the "goings-on" at
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests that a letter of recommendation be sent to Mr. Beverley, of Virginia, introducing him to people of importance in Dijon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has forwarded observations on the invoice of the "Marquis Lafayette," [in Library of The American Philosophical Society, 347.7 P19] by Mr. [Henry] Laurens. Acknowledges receipt of Commission and returns the bond.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires about James Collins at Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges, with thanks, the receipt of passport for himself and family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announces the arrival of three vessels from Philadelphia which took three prizes and about ninety prisoners; awaits instructions regarding same.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Telling him how much he misses him, and giving him the news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Believes his father [Gov. William Franklin] is in England. He has arrived in Paris and can give good account of the commissions entrusted to him from

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks for certificate respecting the Loan Office certificates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regarding means by which clothing and blankets may be sent to the United States for the next campaign.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a sample of Phosphorous candles.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deplores the loss of the frigate "Eagle"; its effect on commerce. Hopes for peace. Refuses to apply for a Consulship after the treatment he has received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His proposed purchase of "old Gen. [Charles] Lee's " estate in Virginia and the death of the latter. Remarks on his peculiar and disagreeable character. The situation as he sees it in America; the blockading of the ports by the English; the death of Col. [John] Laurens in a skirmish near Charlestown; changes that have taken place in the country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Received a letter from Mrs. Rainsford, an English lady, who had a desire to see him and his father Dr. Franklin, but could not wait.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests a letter of introduction of friends in Lyons, Marseilles, Toulon, and permits to remain in these places.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Highly pleased with the intelligence from America. Is encouraged by some success in his mission. Stands well with foreign Ministers. Requests a book on Spain by Mr. [Richard] Cumberland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In behalf of a friend who wishes to inform himself about the United States Government.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Letter written in Mr. [Robert] Morris's cypher number 4."
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is preparing a book on the United States. Requests names of governors, and civil and military officers of each of the thirteen States.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning luggage and packets to be forwarded to the United States.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges, with thanks, receipt of mustard.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges, with thanks, the receipt of information concerning United States.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Friendly inquiries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expressing satisfaction with the country and his intention of remaining. Buys property in Berkley County [Va.] of General [Charles] Lee. Laments death of latter. Rumors of peace with England. National spirit pervades the country. Gaieties in Philadelphia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Personal news and items. Gov. [William] Franklin sailed [for England] on the 18th of September.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging, with thanks, courtesies shown l'Abbé de la Roche-Tilhac.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Portraying sentiments entertained in the United States toward England. Discusses peace terms. Local government.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proffering the gift of a horse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending a groom.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring about the tobacco trade in New England.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Information regarding the tobacco trade in the United States.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Giving an account of cures effected by M. Bonsart at the Invalides.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to forward two packages.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter of thanks.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends squirrel skins.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: De Beche and Graff. St. Sauveur

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending lace ruffles and patterns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regarding rumors of peace. If Dr. Franklin wishes to convey the news to America, he can have a fast-sailing brig at sea at twenty-four hours notice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting letters of introduction to influential people in Geneva. Leghorn and Florence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a pass for Mr. Bird.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring as to the advisability of sending supplies to the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arranging an interview.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting him to dine with him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returning money lent.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regarding money taken in mistake by a courier.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires about the risk attending the sending of vessels to the United States during the peace negotiations.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Answer to inquiry about boxes of seeds.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Giving cost of his vessel. Many wise people doubt a general peace. He thinks it clear and will govern himself accordingly.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Soliciting aid for Captain Hardy. Request a suit of old clothes of Benjamin Franklin's with which to dress a wax figure of him made by Madame [Patience] Wright and to be set up in his study.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Replying to inquiries regarding trade in the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging, with thanks, receipt of the certificate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Soliciting Franklin's influence to obtain permission for him to act in his military capacity, pending an exchange of prisoners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rejoicing upon the full establishment of American Independence.
