scopecontent.p: Tells of her sorrow and distress on his departure. Narrates her visit to Paris and her dislike of the city. Received a letter from Mlle. B[rillion] describing Dr. Franklin's and his grandson's departure from Passy. Bids him adieu, as he is to sail next day, August 1st.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expresses his sorrow at seeing him leaving for America. Hopes to see him again but thinks his best prospects are in America.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Package which he gave to [Louis Guillaume] Le Veillard to deliver to her. Tells of Mlle. M----'s visit to her and the episode of the portrait given to the latter by him. Is treated well now and enjoys a little more freedom. Alludes to M. B[rillon]. Is looking forward to his return to France.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning various commissions which he promised to attend to for him. Sends last messages to some of his fellow passengers; urges his speedy return to France.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets his inability to show civilities to Le Ray de Chaumont [fils]. Gives news of various friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Does not know how to forward her letters to America; tells of departure of his cousins from St. Germain. Saw M. Brillon lately, who told of a proposed marriage for his daughter.Tells of her children and how she passes her time.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells of [Louis Guillaume] Le Veillard's visit to her and the details he gave of his and Dr. Franklin's departure from Havre. Has arranged with him how to forward her letters. Alludes to Mlle. Brillon's coming marriage.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pleasure on hearing of Dr. Franklin's arrival in Philadelphia and of his reception.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Welcoming him home. Anxious to hear about various friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The discovery of numerous debts contracted in Dr. Franklin's name by his steward, Finck; how the latter defrauded the trades people; the scandalous and false reports he is spreading about Dr. Franklin and his grandson. Particulars about the arrest of Cardinal de Rohan in the affair of the Queen's necklace; the Exposition of Paintings and Sculpture. Tells of his plans for the future. Learns that William Temple Franklin's baggage is still at Havre.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Baggage remained at Havre. Is sorry for [Jean Antoine] Houdon, also, who had to leave behind him all his effects, tools, etc.; his works having their usual success at the Salon. Dined at St. Germain lately; alludes to William Temple Franklin's liaison with Mme. Caillot. Is sending him a few pairs of socks and wooden shoes. Has not been able yet to get the roebucks for him. Tells of the coming marriage of Mlle. Brillon de Jouy to M. de Malachelle.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Speaks of Mlle. Brillon's marriage; fears she will not be happy. Gives particulars of the latter's future husband. Cannot forgive Dr. Franklin for not remaining in France, as he had intended. Tells of affairs in her family circle.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deplores the uncertainty as to the dispatch of her letters; vessels not sailing at any fixed dates. Encloses a lock of her hair.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just learned, from Le Veillard, of his safe arrival in America and the ovation given to Dr. Franklin. Is displeased at his not writing to her at once.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Comments on the reception given Dr. Franklin on his arrival. Is disappointed that William Temple Franklin's letter to him did not contain one for [Mme. Caillot]. Refers to the wooden shoes he is sending and to shipping the roebucks. Tells of M. Le Franc's desertion of his wife and children.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fears that the stamp of "St. Germain" on her letters may reveal her identity to the inquisitive. Complains that she has not received a single letter yet from him since his arrival. Tells of her quiet life and her two children.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has executed his commissions. The Jersey deed remains in the hands of Judge [Isaac] Smith, at Trenton, and the New York deed is left with Mr. [John] Jay.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to a note from Le Veillard telling her of a sailing for America. Has read accounts in the newspapers of Dr. Franklin's and his grandson's voyage. Asks for particulars about life and society in Philadelphia; refers to Mme. le B----- whom she hates, and hopes he does not write to her. Expresses her sentiments towards him in a verse of poetry; considers Ovid superior to Seneca. Tells of the books she reads and her delight in translations of Shakespeare.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Le Veillard, Louis Guillaume. Passy.; Lawrence, Ino

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reproaches him for not having written to [Mme. Caillot] since his arrival. Reminds him of his duty towards her and the sacrifices she made for him. The roebucks are in the Royal Menagerie; but thinks it is folly to try to ship them to America. M. [Louis Antoine] de Bougainville affirms he saw and killed some in Canada. Begs him not to neglect to ship the young trees and to add several more for the Duchess d'Enville. Refers to M. [Lair] de Lamotte, Mme. [Le Ray] de Chaumont, etc.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives items of news about the theatres and the plays presented. Tells of the death of the Duc d'Orleans who is succeeded by his son the Duc de Chartres, of the death of Grammont and of Mme. Dutartre. Refers to quarrel between [Pierre Augustin Caron de] Beaumarchais and [Comte de] Mirabeau. News about the Le Veillard family.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will deliver the packet to [David] Hartley on his arrival in London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to a friendly letter received from Dr. Franklin. Is prevented by her family from seeing William Temple Franklin; speaks of his departure from France and begs him to write to her often.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells of her fears and distress when he did not come to the inn where they were to meet; was ashamed to be seen in the place. Refers to the bond that unites them; is ready to defy all obstacles to their affection.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is about to cast a statue in bronze and invites him to see the operation.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to a trip he may make to France.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a young man who wishes to cross, gratis, to America under the title of Mr. Franklin's Secretary.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Duke of Choiseul's illness and death has prevented him from calling on Dr. Franklin; will breakfast with him the next day; will show a bargain in whale oil which, if approved, will be sent to Boston.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires if Dr. Franklin's house is to be let after his departure. Mme. de Montconsul[?] and her daughter, Princess d'Henin, his intimate friends, wish to have a house at

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hears from America that Dr. Franklin's resignation has been accepted and that Mr. [Thomas] Jefferson is to stay in France; Mr. [John] Adams, wtih William Smith, of New York, as Secretary, has been appointed Minister at London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Comte de Bethune's offer for the purchase of his carriage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a letter of introduction to Mr. [Benjamin] Vaughan, of London, for M.de Launay de Tillières.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Relating to the disposal of his clothes before leaving Paris.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jesting inquiry about his conduct in New York and allusions to their love affairs in Philadelphia. References to M. de Villers and Holker.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: [Jean Antoine] Houdon has returned; asks to be instructed in the political situation in Pennsylvania. January 27. Received letters from Benjamin [Franklin Bache] and Dr. Franklin; hopes Dr. Franklin is not annoyed by the political situation; offers some suggestions on this.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received her first letter since his arrival in America. Expects others by [Jean Antoine] Houdon who has returned. Is treated well by her husband; would give her life for him but can never give him back her love. Tells of visit she made to the B[rillon] family; thinks them greatly changed by their increasing wealth. Mme. P[aris] has lost all her beauty since her marriage.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for further information about the offer made him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thinks favorably of one of his proposals; makes an arrangement to visit the farm with him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives plan of agreement proposed by Mr. [William] Pyne; speak of the advantages of cattle fairs, and the profit in a well-managed and well-stocked farm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fears that he will soon forget the Paris he liked so well and now soon return to France. Describes her life and the society she moves in at St. Germain. Gives particulars about Mme. P[aris] and her sister. Thanks Mrs. [John] Jay for her remembrance.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Williams will send the trees and plants; the books have not been sent because Mr. Manuel is in the Bastille.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arranges for the meeting with [William] Pyne to take place at his house.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His reason for consenting to Mr. [George] Morgan's plan for the meeting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing receipt of Captain Lauber for two cases of shruberry and grains sent to Mr. Le Veillard.
(In French. In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Draft of the agreement with William Temple Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offering to sell certain things required for stocking the farm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reproaches him for blaming her for the death of her young son. Refers to Dr. Franklin's desire to see his grandson married; declares she is resigned to the idea, but advises him, in that case, not to come back to France. Tells of her visit to Mme. [Jeanne Louise Henriette Genet] Campan, at Versailles. Offers to get a portrait of Mme. le B----- for him. Will send him the sum of money she has belonging to him.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Making an appointment to meet him at Burlington; has not been able to find a cook; Mrs. [George] Morgan offers to sell one who is a "complete servant" for £80.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will send the roebucks by the first opportunity from Havre; all their friends are well; is it true that he (William Temple Franklin) is to be a member of Congress? Introduces Mr. De la Valette.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certain implements are promised but he cannot find suitable horses; makes an appointment to meet him at the farm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: About domestic affairs at the farm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will fill all the commissions as soon as possible; goes to Dreux to meet his brother-in-law just returned from India; Mr. [Thomas] Jefferson is in England.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells of the misfortunes which have happened to her; her father's dangerous illness; her infant son's death. Advises him to remain in America if his interests and prospects require it. Protests her undying affection for him whether he comes back or not.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking him to purchase iron wire for his electric rods.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advising him of the shipping of two chests.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. De la Valette will bring the dog, the shoes and the remainder of the books; Mr. [J. T.] Bérard was so slow in sending the trees that they were in leaf; the roebucks are too ill to send; the suit continues against the Cardinal [Rohan] who hopes to prove that he was only a dupe.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her young daughter is still seriously ill with fever. Asks for particulars about his country place. Tells of the death of Mme. Paris's [née Brillon] infant son. Wishes to hear about Dr. Franklin in every letter.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him to buy some wheat or rye for bread, also three bushels of white potatoes, and to bring some money.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Cardinal [Rohan]'s suit is about being decided; it seems to be turning in his favor; he will be declared an imbecile.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges the receipt of a letter from Dr. Franklin; has written to him often; has accomplished all his commissions; tells where his various friends are; will try to find a music and singing master willing to go to America; he will also try to find a carpenter; thanks him for the ham.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives the price of Lucerne [alfalfa].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking him to buy gears for the wagon and a half sheep; only two shad have been caught as yet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presents a copy of his "Aerial Narrative" and a proof print of his historical portrait.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Received a visit from Mme. Malachelle [née Brillon]. Alludes to [Louis Guillaume] Le Veillard's illness. Swears that William Temple Franklin was the cause of much pain and sorrow to her in the past, but has forgiven him. Begs him not to take any women in service in his house. Encloses verses by Chevalier [Evariste Désiré de Forges] de Parny on the instability of happiness.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks that the wagon be sent to meet him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The roebucks will not be ready to leave before September; the King took a trip to Cherbourg, he was well received, the Queen was not with him.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is convinced now that he does not intend to return to France. Reproaches him mildly for not having a letter ready to send her once a month by each vessel. Describes how she keeps all her letters in book form. Tells of all the Brillon family and of her husband's dislike of Passy. Remarks on how men do nothing to keep their wives' love until it is too late and they have lost it.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for information concerning Mr. John Morris who went to New York in the year 1783 with a cargo of goods which he sold to good account; his subsequent purchase of an estate in or around Philadelphia in 1785; no word received from him since that time his relatives anxious to know if he is living.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to a long journey he was to undertake; does not understand how it can secure him an appointment as Minister in Europe. Tells of Mme. Brillon's two daughters. Infers from his letters that he intends to get married soon; sees that it was a grievous fault to love him and that she is now paying the penalty.
In French.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Du Pont de Nemours, Pierre Samuel, 1739-1817

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Particularly recommending M. [John] Bourne to his kind attentions.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for the political news; gives news of various friends; sorry to hear about the affair of the paper money.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explains his position in regard to the memorial of the French claims presented to Congress.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reflections on the charms of liberty. Thinks she could never accustom herself to the manner of living in America; her idea of the women in America. Prefers to live where she is than anywhere else in the world. Tells how she intends to spend the winter at Paris, Versailles and Croissy. Has declined a part in a play to be acted at Mme. le B-----'s, at Versailles; the Comte d'Artois to be present. C[aillot] to act in two rôles; many will go to see him.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. [Jean Baptiste] Le Roy says that four of the roebucks are dead and the other three sick. September 20. Mr. [Thomas] Jefferson hurt his wrist. Mr. Le Coutteux has married a young wife and is going to Pennsylvania. Effect of the King of Prussia [Frederick the Great]'s death. September 23. Thanks him for his kindness about the American Philosophical Society, of Philadelphia; feels that this honor is only shown because of William Temple Franklin's and Dr. Franklin's interest; offers to do what he can for it. October 15. Mr. [Thomas] Jefferson sends books, the new volumes of the New Encyclopedia, etc.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Would invite him to stay with him except for the serious illness of his child.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the dismissal of the Pynes. Recommends some farm hands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Items of news about the Brillon family and other acquaintances of his. Was a guest at Count de V.'s for several days. Talked a good deal about America with the Vicomte. Met Abbé de la Roche in the same house; Comte d'Artois was also present and admired her little daughter.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges four copies of Humphry Marshall's "Arbustum Americanum" to be given to Messrs. de la Rochefoucauld, de Malesherbes, de Barbançon and himself.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sorry to be from home when he and Mr. Lawrence called; if a time is named, he will be home and will give all the information possible about the boundaries of Governor [William] Franklin's farm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells of a conversation she had with Abbé de la Roche about Dr. Franklin and his grandson. Declares she has no longer any desire to please or receive homages; at 29 years of age has renounced all frivolity and pleasures; never expects now to see him again. Tells of a visit she made to the Brillon family, at Paris, and refers to Le Veillard's son and Mlle. Dillon's death.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is most anxious to help his friend, John Hurd; thinks Mr. [Thomas] Jefferson should be empowered to do this business, since Dr. Franklin has resigned.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him a new assortment of trees for planting; difficulties encountered by M. [Jean Baptiste] Le Roy in sending the deer. Financial affairs; rumor of the establishment of a National Bank. Tragic fate of the Marquis de [Sourches-] Tourzel who was thrown from his horse and killed. Desiring news of him and his grandfather; hears he has acquired some land in the Jerseys.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Intends to leave the country soon to return to St. Germain and from there to Versailles.
(In French. Enclosed in previous letter.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter for Dr. Franklin.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposes in future to send her letters to Le Veillard [fils] to be forwarded by him. Has heard from Bé[lloy] that he intends to return to Europe and reside in London.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Attributes M. Dai-----'s illness and M. Brillon's to their excessive use of medicine, pills, etc. Laments the breaking up and dispersal of the society of Passy; finds her only consolation in her daughter. Tells of the friendship shown her by the young ladies of the convent; invited them to dine with her on Christmas evening.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to give an enclosed paper to the President [Dr. Franklin.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers him a place in his post chaise to go to Mr. [William] Hamilton's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells of the work being done.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fears the horses may not get back that night; they are over-worked; will look out for another.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting a loan of twenty dollars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers to draw plans for a building similar to the plans already seen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Believes that Dr. Franklin, he and Benjamin [Franklin Bache] have forgotten their friends in France because they do not write; Madame de Chabot is dead; the King has called the Assembly of the Notables to meet at Versailles in February.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has not yet found the portrait of the Prince de Brunswick; his health has not been good so cannot go to Paris as often as formerly. If he were younger he would love to go to America; the Notables have arrived in Versailles, hopes they will make things better. Dr. Franklin has apparently forgotten him; thanks William Temple Franklin for his kindness about the American Philosophical Society; enquires what is known about ancient towns on the Ohio, especially in Kentucky.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Much is happening here at present; the Notable Assembly is in session; there is a deficit of one hundred millions in the revenues of the King; gives the plans for meeting this deficit. Mr. Brillon is very ill. Mr. [John] Adams has just published a book. 1 Believes that Dr. Franklin has forgotten him. The affair of [Cardinal de] Rohan has reversed all the hopes.
In French.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: 1 A Defense of the Constitutions of Government of the United States of America, London, 1787.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. [John] Beckley, the Clerk of this Assembly, has gone on to the [Constitutional] Convention with Governor [Edmund] Randolph, hoping to be made its Secretary. He [William Temple Franklin] should try for this position.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him for discounting the notes; complains of poor health.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has sent Mme. le B-----'s portrait to him. Tells of M. Brillon's death at Nice; his son-in-law, M. de Malachelle succeeds him in his position. Hears that their house at Passy is to be sold. Contrasts the pleasures of life in France with the lack of them in America; tells of the agreeable society she moves in.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives the news about his friends since he last wrote; also he tells what was done by the Notable Assembly since that date.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Owing to his poor health he is obliged to give up house-keeping.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is having a copy made from his portrait to send to him. Mme. Brillon has determined to keep her own house; her daughters to live with her. Doubts whether the portrait she is sending is really for an aunt.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives news of his friends and what was done by the Notable Assembly; could not find Schrode's engraving of Prince of Brunswick, so sent another; wishes to know how much money would be needed to live in comfort in Philadelphia; regrets that Mr. [Thomas] Jefferson is not a member of the [Constitutional] Convention; introduces Mr. Saugrain.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends by Captain Lawton two packages with letter and receipt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him to send his endorsement for about $3,000, as B[ache] and S[hee] are not in cash to pay off the whole of the last note, which ought to have been taken up yesterday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the stockings; asks his help to collect a debt; encloses a letter.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells of the flight of M. [Charles Alexandre] de Calonne; gives the political situation in Paris; Passy is much changed; gives the account of the seizure of Mr. [Thomas] Paine's model of a bridge; wishes to hear the news of the [Constitutional] Convention in America; asks Dr. Franklin for the promised history.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the package sent by the Amboy stage boat.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Learns from [Louis Guillaume] Le Veillard that his portrait is copied from the original loaned by her. Refers to return of Chevalier de la Luzerne; thinks William Temple Franklin should be appointed Minister to France. Tells of her approaching confinement. The Brillon family in great consternation owing to the death of Mme. Paris, their oldest child. Recalls the time when Dr. Franklin called her his daughter and showed her so much affection.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Attended to the business but thought it best not to put his "name in nomination," as Mr. [Thomas] McKean said that Dr. Franklin appeared to wish that he be not run.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has heard that Dr. Franklin is to be President of the new Congress; gives news of his various friends.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has made arrangements that, in case of death or serious accident to her, the little green box (containing his portrait, etc.) will be handed over to M. [Louis Guillaume] Le Veillard; the latter in very precarious health.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells little items of news about Dr. Franklin, and of his desire to see him; visits of her children to the latter. Refers to the sailing of the "Alliance." Tells of Dr. Franklin's signing a marriage license or Mrs. Kepple, a rich widow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will visit at the Park as soon as possible; has made a good invention or making silk lines and snoods.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends friendly message from Mme. le B----. Learns from M. Louis Guillaume] Le Veillard that his health is not improving.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes that Congress has adopted the decisions of the [Constitutional] Convention; has bought and sent the glass for the electric machines; asks for information about certain business firms; the capitalists of the large towns are now occupied with American funds under the name of "Liquidated Debts." Gives news of various friends.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing change in firm and giving signatures.
(In French. In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tells of the birth of her child [Armand] which almost cost her life. Gives news of Mme. Brillon's two married daughters.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes all information possible about America; his son is anxious to go there.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives statement of his affairs with the firm; thanks him for his trouble in the affair with Mr. [Thomas] Barclay; delighted that Dr. Franklin is in such good health; will send grain and books at first opportunity. Asks him to collect a debt from J. B. Ross. April 2. Thanks him for the plants for his garden, in return he will send books; Mr. [Thomas] Jefferson has gone to feel the pulse of the good Dutch.
(In French. In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has sent several letters by Mr. Bourgoin who is waiting to deliver them in person, if it is possible to get them, he advises that this be done as quickly as possible; everything is in a great state of confusion.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Because of the expensiveness of the wine, he ordered half the quantity; he encloses the bill of lading.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has had many business troubles and disappointments; would like to go to America; asks for information about the cost of living; expresses great devotion for him and his grandfather.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The political state is very uncertain; the States-General will be called in 1789.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Country is in a most upset state; "all the Provinces protest against the new measures as giving to the Court too great influence over the property of the people and taking away the sole barrier to check the Ministry." Sweden and Russia have begun to put in action a long smothered enmity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing the drafts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a medallion proof-print of their [Britannic] Majesties.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notification of his election to the Burlington Society for the Pronotion of Agriculture and of Domestic Manufactures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking him to secure the refusal of the two houses, in Philadelphia, poken of. His object in taking two is to use the lower floor of oth for his public offices and the first floor and both gardens for his own use. Would like Mr. [Edmund] Randolph, the Attorney-General, or his neighbor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning his intended payment of two bills which are about to fall due.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will call and take dinner with him some day.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. [John] Lardner who is going to Paris on a visit; he has offered to take charge of some squirrel skins which she is sending to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting him to dine with her.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets he had not his company at the race. Declines invitation to dine at

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting payment of his bill for flowers, and sending a power of attorney from ----- Bates.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Quoting prices of costumes.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a copy of the Unique, presented to her by Dr. Franklin; her high opinion of it. Will be out all day; puts her viol at his disposal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to return the letter from Martinique.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The answer to his letter was unfavorable; asks that Dr. Franklin write certain papers for him.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Mr. Benjamin Vaughan's bill. Mr. Thomas Barclay's accounts.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed notice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him to tell what he knows about him to the bearer of the letter, who is the mother of a lad he is taking to America.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Laneuville, Louis Pierre Panot Lombart, chevalier de, 1744-ca.1800

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to send, by bearer, a few bottles of Bordeaux wine.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has delivered his challenge to ----- Leadwell who has accepted it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to see the "Craftsman" containing Mr. Braxton's letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him to lend him last Saturday's Mercury. Sends back the key of the garden door.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending the remarks of Vaugelas and Père Bonhours.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the address of M. de Varseille[?].
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing him that Denis Carcot has left for London.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks him and his father for an invitation to dinner, but will have to postpone the pleasure until the following week.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invites him to assist at a meeting of the French Academy.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends memoir concerning certain persons, Cardinal de Rohan desiring to ascertain if they are known to Dr. Franklin and are deserving of the assistance they solicit.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received Dr. Franklin's reply to Cardinal de Rohan's inquiry the latter has done all he can to have Darbelot [a former servant of Dr. Franklin] admitted to the Quinze-Vingt Asylum for the Blind.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepts his invitation and requests him to ask Mme. Brillon to loan them one of her pianos for the occasion.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting him to be present at a meeting of a Society for giving balls, dances, etc.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fixing date for dinner at Neuilly.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His father has decided not to go to Spa but to remain with him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to postpone his invitation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting him to a family dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Telling of the virtues of castor oil and the mode of taking it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returning books loaned by William Temple Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to pass an evening at his house.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires about Dr. Franklin's health; also about the affair of [Richmond] Springer and his comrades at Brest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to return to the writer his letter for Chevalier de Chastellux, which he will deliver in person.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a memoir to be forwarded to London and translated into English.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of a wine grower who wishes to find a market for his wines in America; would send samples to [Richard] Bache and make arrangements with him.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking information about Mlle. Andrillon who was employed as a child nurse by Mrs. [John] Jay, when the latter was living at Dr. Franklin's.
In French.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Child's letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Difficulties and sufferings since imprisonment of his dear father; mentions others made prisoners. Desires to be remembered to her father [Dr. Franklin] and Aunt Mecom.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bust being sent. Letters to father "might give suspicions." Squirrel skins for coat. B.F. requested cotton for a Lady. Mentions Mr. Brown, M. Gerard.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Americans in Paris; birth of the dauphin. Mentions his grandfather.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News of the war in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mentions R. Bache, furs and J. Vaughan. Fruit to B.F. Caustic comments on American Ladies in Paris: Mrs. Jay, Price, Izard, Ridly. Mentions his father. Lord Shelburne communicates with B.F.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In French. Introduces M. Putnam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwards copy of resolve of Congress, pegging rate of U. S. dollars to the French livre Tournois.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends letter to be forwarded to his father [William Franklin], and a parcel containing contraband goods for Dr. Bancroft.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Purchased from the American Autograph Shop, April 1939, $33.

did.unittitle: Letter to [Donatien] Le Ray de Chaumont

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of M. de Chaumont's son in America; B. Franklin's arrival in Rouen; Abbé Morellet's desire to possess a certain tapestry armchair once used by Franklin. In French.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Purchased from George W. Dalton, November 1938, $75.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His grandfather stood journey to Havre well; arrangements made with Capt. Truxton. Investigation of box containing papers and books. Arrival of M. Houdon.

did.unittitle: Contract with William Pyne for managing a farm in New Jersey

did.abstract: The signatures have been blotted out.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Objections to contract on managing farm.

did.unittitle: Sketch of William Temple Franklin's services on the United States of America; Passy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to go to England and France; offers services to Washington. Purpose in going is to derive advantage from the publication of his grandfather's Works, and not because of disgust and disappointment in not receiving governmental appointment. His loyalty to America, its laws and its Chief Magistrate.

scopecontent.p: Asks that the 91 volumes of the Histoire de l'Academie bequeathed by his grandfather to the Philosophical society be sent for.
